items.text: **Croatia** (/kroʊˈeɪʃə/ ( ) kroh-AY-shə; [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_language|Croatian]]: *Hrvatska* [xř̩ʋaːtskaː] ), officially the **Republic of Croatia** (Croatian: *Republika Hrvatska*, ), is a country situated at the crossroads of [[LINK|lang_en|Central_Europe|Central]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Southeast_Europe|Southeast Europe]], on the [[LINK|lang_en|Adriatic_Sea|Adriatic Sea]]. Its capital city is [[LINK|lang_en|Zagreb|Zagreb]], which forms one of the country's [[LINK|lang_en|Administrative_divisions_of_Croatia|primary subdivisions]], along with its [[LINK|lang_en|Counties_of_Croatia|twenty counties]]. Croatia has a total area of 56,594 square kilometres (21,851 square miles) and a population of 4.28 million, most of whom are [[LINK|lang_en|Catholic_Church|Roman Catholics]].
The Croats arrived in the area of present-day Croatia during the early part of the 7th century AD.
They organised the state into two duchies by the 9th century.

[[LINK|lang_en|Tomislav_of_Croatia|Tomislav]] became the first king by 925, elevating Croatia to the status of a kingdom. The [[LINK|lang_en|Kingdom_of_Croatia_(925–1102)|Kingdom of Croatia]] retained its sovereignty for nearly two centuries, reaching its peak during the rule of Kings [[LINK|lang_en|Peter_Krešimir_IV_of_Croatia|Petar Krešimir IV]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Demetrius_Zvonimir_of_Croatia|Dmitar Zvonimir]]. Croatia entered a [[LINK|lang_en|Croatia_in_the_union_with_Hungary|personal union]] with [[LINK|lang_en|Kingdom_of_Hungary|Hungary]] in 1102. In 1527, faced with [[LINK|lang_en|Hundred_Years'_Croatian–Ottoman_War|Ottoman conquest]], the Croatian Parliament elected [[LINK|lang_en|Ferdinand_I,_Holy_Roman_Emperor|Ferdinand I]] of the [[LINK|lang_en|House_of_Habsburg|House of Habsburg]] to the Croatian throne. During the early 19th century, parts of the country were split into the [[LINK|lang_en|Illyrian_Provinces|French Illyrian Provinces]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Austria-Hungary|Austria-Hungary]] occupied its Bosnia and Herzegovina side–a dispute settled by the [[LINK|lang_en|Treaty_of_Berlin_(1878)|1878 Treaty of Berlin]]. In 1918, after [[LINK|lang_en|World_War_I|World War I]], Croatia was included in the unrecognized [[LINK|lang_en|State_of_Slovenes,_Croats_and_Serbs|State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs]] which seceded from [[LINK|lang_en|Austria-Hungary|Austria-Hungary]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Creation_of_Yugoslavia|merged into]] the [[LINK|lang_en|Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia|Kingdom of Yugoslavia]]. A [[LINK|lang_en|Independent_State_of_Croatia|fascist Croatian puppet state]] backed by Fascist Italy and Nazi Germany existed in [[LINK|lang_en|World_War_II|World War II]]. After the war, Croatia became a founding member and a federal constituent of the [[LINK|lang_en|Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia|Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]], a constitutionally [[LINK|lang_en|Socialist_state|socialist state]]. On 25 June 1991, Croatia [[LINK|lang_en|Independence_of_Croatia|declared independence]], which came wholly into effect on 8 October of the same year. The [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_War_of_Independence|Croatian War of Independence]] was fought successfully for four years following the declaration.

Croatia is a [[LINK|lang_en|Republic|republic]] governed under a [[LINK|lang_en|Parliamentary_system|parliamentary system]] and a developed economy with a very high [[LINK|lang_en|Human_Development_Index|Human Development Index]]. Croatia is a member of the [[LINK|lang_en|European_Union|European Union]] (EU), [[LINK|lang_en|United_Nations|United Nations]] (UN), the [[LINK|lang_en|Council_of_Europe|Council of Europe]], [[LINK|lang_en|NATO|NATO]], the [[LINK|lang_en|World_Trade_Organization|World Trade Organization]] (WTO) and a founding member of the [[LINK|lang_en|Union_for_the_Mediterranean|Union for the Mediterranean]]. As an active participant in the [[LINK|lang_en|United_Nations_peacekeeping|UN peacekeeping forces]], Croatia has contributed troops to the [[LINK|lang_en|International_Security_Assistance_Force|NATO-led mission in Afghanistan]] and took a non-permanent seat on the [[LINK|lang_en|United_Nations_Security_Council|UN Security Council]] for the 2008–2009 term.

The [[LINK|lang_en|Service_sector|service sector]] dominates Croatia's economy, followed by the [[LINK|lang_en|Industrial_sector|industrial sector]] and agriculture. [[LINK|lang_en|Tourism_in_Croatia|International tourism]] is a significant source of revenue during the summer, with Croatia ranked the 18th most popular tourist destination in the world. The state controls a part of the economy, with substantial government expenditure. The European Union is Croatia's most important [[LINK|lang_en|International_trade|trading partner]]. Since 2000, the Croatian government has constantly invested in infrastructure, especially [[LINK|lang_en|Transport_in_Croatia|transport routes and facilities]] along the [[LINK|lang_en|Pan-European_corridors|Pan-European corridors]]. Internal sources produce a significant portion of [[LINK|lang_en|Energy_in_Croatia|energy in Croatia]]; the rest is imported. Croatia provides a [[LINK|lang_en|Universal_health_care|universal health care]] system and free [[LINK|lang_en|Education_in_Croatia|primary and secondary education]], while supporting [[LINK|lang_en|Culture_of_Croatia|culture]] through numerous public institutions and corporate investments in [[LINK|lang_en|Media_of_Croatia|media]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_literature|publishing]].
Etymology

The [[LINK|lang_en|Name_of_Croatia|name of Croatia]] derives from [[LINK|lang_en|Medieval_Latin|Medieval Latin]] *Croātia*. Compare *DUX CRUATORVM* [ *[[LINK|lang_en|Sic|sic]] * ] ("Duke of the Croats") attested in the [[LINK|lang_en|Branimir_inscription|Branimir inscription]]. Itself a derivation of [[LINK|lang_en|North-West_Slavic|North-West Slavic]] **Xrovat-*, by [[LINK|lang_en|Liquid_metathesis|liquid metathesis]] from proposed [[LINK|lang_en|Common_Slavic|Common Slavic]] period *[[LINK|lang_en|https://en.wiktionary.orgReconstruction:Proto-Slavic/xorvatъ|*Xorvat]] *, from proposed [[LINK|lang_en|Proto-Slavic|Proto-Slavic]] **Xarwāt-* (**Xъrvatъ*) or **Xŭrvatŭ* (**xъrvatъ*).

The origin of the name is uncertain, but is thought to be a [[LINK|lang_en|Gothic_language|Gothic]] or [[LINK|lang_en|Indo-Aryan_languages|Indo-Aryan]] term assigned to a [[LINK|lang_en|Slavic_peoples|Slavic tribe]]. [[CITE|276|http://kuscholarworks.ku.edu/dspace/bitstream/1808/969/1/yugoslav_myths96.pdf]] The oldest preserved record of the Croatian [[LINK|lang_en|Ethnonym|ethnonym]] *xъrvatъ is of variable stem, attested in the [[LINK|lang_en|Baška_tablet|Baška tablet]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Style_(manner_of_address)|style]] *zvъnъmirъ kralъ xrъvatъskъ* ("[[LINK|lang_en|Dmitar_Zvonimir|Zvonimir]], Croatian king"). [[CITE|301|http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=21348&show=clanak]]

The first attestation of the Latin term is attributed to a charter of Duke [[LINK|lang_en|Trpimir_I_of_Croatia|Trpimir]] from the year 852. The original is lost, and just a 1568 copy is preserved, leading to doubts over the authenticity of the claim. The oldest preserved stone inscription is the 9th-century Branimir Inscription found near [[LINK|lang_en|Benkovac|Benkovac]], where Duke [[LINK|lang_en|Branimir_of_Croatia|Branimir]] is styled as *Dux Cruatorvm*. The [[LINK|lang_en|Inscription|inscription]] is not believed to be dated accurately, but is likely to be from during the period of 879–892, during Branimir's rule.
History
Prehistory and antiquity

The area known as Croatia today was inhabited throughout the [[LINK|lang_en|Prehistoric_period|prehistoric period]]. Fossils of [[LINK|lang_en|Neanderthals|Neanderthals]] dating to the middle [[LINK|lang_en|Paleolithic|Palaeolithic]] period have been unearthed in northern Croatia, with the most famous and the best presented site in [[LINK|lang_en|Krapina|Krapina]]. [[CITE|356|http://worldcat.org/issn/1334-4366]] Remnants of several [[LINK|lang_en|Neolithic|Neolithic]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Chalcolithic|Chalcolithic]] cultures were found in all regions of the country. [[CITE|29|http://worldcat.org/issn/0473-0992]] The largest proportion of the sites is in the river valleys of northern Croatia, and the most significant cultures whose presence was discovered include [[LINK|lang_en|Starčevo_culture|Starčevo]], [[LINK|lang_en|Vučedol_culture|Vučedol]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Baden_culture|Baden cultures]]. [[CITE|54|http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=26644&show=clanak]] The [[LINK|lang_en|Iron_Age|Iron Age]] left traces of the early Illyrian [[LINK|lang_en|Hallstatt_culture|Hallstatt culture]] and the Celtic [[LINK|lang_en|La_Tène_culture|La Tène culture]]. [[CITE|153|http://worldcat.org/issn/1330-0644]]
Greek and Roman rule

Much later, the region was settled by [[LINK|lang_en|Liburnians|Liburnians]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Illyrians|Illyrians]], while the first Greek colonies were established on the islands of [[LINK|lang_en|Korčula|Korčula]], [[LINK|lang_en|Hvar|Hvar]] [[CITE|196|https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Illyrians.html?id=4Nv6SPRKqs8C]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Vis_(island)|Vis]]. [[CITE|240|https://scribd.com/doc/15826619/John-Wilkes-The-Illyrians]] In 9 AD the territory of today's Croatia became part of the [[LINK|lang_en|Roman_Empire|Roman Empire]]. Emperor [[LINK|lang_en|Diocletian|Diocletian]] built a [[LINK|lang_en|Diocletian's_Palace|large palace]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Split,_Croatia|Split]] when he retired in AD 305. [[CITE|280|https://books.google.com/books?id=bdKLyie1M50C]]

During the 5th century, one of the [[LINK|lang_en|Concise_list_of_Roman_emperors#Western_Roman_Empire|last Emperors of the Western Roman Empire]], [[LINK|lang_en|Julius_Nepos|Julius Nepos]], ruled his small empire from the palace. [[CITE|309|https://books.google.com/books?id=Xw4fAAAAMAAJ]] The period ends with [[LINK|lang_en|Avars_(Carpathians)|Avar]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Croats|Croat]] invasions in the first half of the 7th century and destruction of almost all Roman towns. Roman survivors retreated to more favourable sites on the coast, islands and mountains. The city of [[LINK|lang_en|Dubrovnik|Dubrovnik]] was founded by such survivors from [[LINK|lang_en|Epidaurum|Epidaurum]]. [[CITE|331|https://books.google.com/books?id=E_NBAAAAYAAJ]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|Ethnogenesis|ethnogenesis]] of Croats is uncertain and there are several competing theories, *Slavic* and *Iranian* being the most frequently put forward. The most widely accepted of these, the *Slavic* theory, proposes migration of [[LINK|lang_en|White_Croats|White Croats]] from the territory of [[LINK|lang_en|White_Croatia|White Croatia]] during the [[LINK|lang_en|Migration_Period|Migration Period]]. Conversely, the *Iranian* theory proposes [[LINK|lang_en|Iranian_peoples|Iranian]] origin, based on [[LINK|lang_en|Tanais_Tablets|Tanais Tablets]] containing [[LINK|lang_en|Greek_language|Greek]] inscription of given names *Χορούαθ[ος]*, *Χοροάθος*, and *Χορόαθος* (Khoroúathos, Khoroáthos, and Khoróathos) and their interpretation as [[LINK|lang_en|Anthroponym|anthroponyms]] of Croatian people. [[CITE|15|http://worldcat.org/issn/1333-2546]]
Middle Ages

According to the work *[[LINK|lang_en|De_Administrando_Imperio|De Administrando Imperio]] * written by the 10th-century Byzantine Emperor [[LINK|lang_en|Constantine_VII|Constantine VII]], the Croats had arrived in what is today Croatia in the early 7th century; however, that claim is disputed and competing hypotheses date the event between the 6th and the 9th centuries. Eventually two [[LINK|lang_en|Dukedom_(administrative_division)|dukedoms]] were formed— [[LINK|lang_en|Pannonian_Croatia|Duchy of Pannonia]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Duchy_of_Croatia|Duchy of Croatia]], ruled by [[LINK|lang_en|Liudewit|Liudewit]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Borna_of_Croatia|Borna]], as attested by chronicles of [[LINK|lang_en|Einhard|Einhard]] starting in 818. The record represents the first document of Croatian realms, [[LINK|lang_en|Vassal_states|vassal states]] of [[LINK|lang_en|Francia|Francia]] at the time.

The Frankish overlordship ended during the reign of [[LINK|lang_en|Mislav_of_Croatia|Mislav]] two decades later. According to the Constantine VII [[LINK|lang_en|Christianization|Christianization]] of Croats began in the 7th century, but the claim is disputed and generally Christianization is associated with the 9th century. [[CITE|98|http://worldcat.org/issn/0352-3101]] The first native Croatian ruler recognised by the Pope was Duke Branimir, who received papal recognition from [[LINK|lang_en|Pope_John_VIII|Pope John VIII]] on 7 June 879.

[[LINK|lang_en|Tomislav_of_Croatia|Tomislav]] was the first ruler of Croatia who was styled a king in a letter from the [[LINK|lang_en|Pope_John_X|Pope John X]], dating kingdom of Croatia to year 925. Tomislav defeated Hungarian and [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian–Bulgarian_battle_of_926|Bulgarian invasions]], spreading the influence of Croatian kings. [[CITE|160|http://worldcat.org/issn/0353-295X]] The medieval Croatian kingdom reached its peak in the 11th century during the reigns of [[LINK|lang_en|Petar_Krešimir_IV_of_Croatia|Petar Krešimir IV]] (1058–1074) and [[LINK|lang_en|Demetrius_Zvonimir_of_Croatia|Dmitar Zvonimir]] (1075–1089). [[CITE|209|http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=76963&show=clanak]] When [[LINK|lang_en|Stephen_II_of_Croatia|Stjepan II]] died in 1091 ending the [[LINK|lang_en|House_of_Trpimirović|Trpimirović]] dynasty, [[LINK|lang_en|Ladislaus_I_of_Hungary|Ladislaus I of Hungary]] claimed the Croatian crown in name of his sister [[LINK|lang_en|Helena_of_Hungary,_Queen_of_Croatia|Helena]], wife of King Dmitar Zvonimir. Opposition to the claim led to a [[LINK|lang_en|Battle_of_Gvozd_Mountain|war]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Croatia_in_personal_union_with_Hungary|personal union of Croatia and Hungary]] in 1102, ruled by [[LINK|lang_en|Coloman,_King_of_Hungary|Coloman]]. [[CITE|287|http://worldcat.org/issn/1332-4853]]

For the next four centuries, the Kingdom of Croatia was ruled by the [[LINK|lang_en|Sabor|Sabor]] (parliament) and a [[LINK|lang_en|Ban_of_Croatia|Ban]] (viceroy) appointed by the king. [[CITE|339|https://web.archive.org/web/20101202061135/http://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?sec=404]] The period saw increasing threat of [[LINK|lang_en|Ottoman_Empire|Ottoman]] conquest and struggle against the [[LINK|lang_en|Republic_of_Venice|Republic of Venice]] for control of coastal areas. The Venetians gained control over most of Dalmatia by 1428, with exception of the [[LINK|lang_en|Republic_of_Ragusa|city-state of Dubrovnik]] which became independent. [[LINK|lang_en|Hundred_Years'_Croatian–Ottoman_War|Ottoman conquests]] led to the 1493 [[LINK|lang_en|Battle_of_Krbava_field|Battle of Krbava field]] and 1526 [[LINK|lang_en|Battle_of_Mohács|Battle of Mohács]], both ending in decisive Ottoman victories. King [[LINK|lang_en|Louis_II_of_Hungary|Louis II]] died at Mohács, and in 1527, the [[LINK|lang_en|1527_election_in_Cetin|Croatian Parliament met in Cetin]] and chose Ferdinand I of the [[LINK|lang_en|House_of_Habsburg|House of Habsburg]] as new ruler of Croatia, under the condition that he provide protection to Croatia against the Ottoman Empire while respecting its political rights. [[CITE|339|https://web.archive.org/web/20101202061135/http://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?sec=404]] This period saw the rise of influential nobility such as the [[LINK|lang_en|Frankopan|Frankopan]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Zrinski|Zrinski]] families to prominence and ultimately numerous Bans from the two families. [[CITE|99|http://worldcat.org/issn/0351-9767]]

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Tanais_Tablets|Tanais Tablet B]], name *Khoroáthos* highlighted

items.text: Habsburg Monarchy and Austria-Hungary (1538–1918)
Following the decisive Ottoman victories, Croatia was split into civilian and military territories, with the partition formed in 1538.

The military territories would become known as the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Military_Frontier|Croatian Military Frontier]] and were under direct Imperial control. Ottoman advances in the Croatian territory continued until the 1593 [[LINK|lang_en|Battle_of_Sisak|Battle of Sisak]], the first decisive Ottoman defeat, and stabilisation of borders.

During the [[LINK|lang_en|Great_Turkish_War|Great Turkish War]] (1683–1698), [[LINK|lang_en|Slavonia|Slavonia]] was regained but western [[LINK|lang_en|Bosnia|Bosnia]], which had been part of Croatia before the Ottoman conquest, remained outside Croatian control. The present-day border between the two countries is a remnant of this outcome. [[LINK|lang_en|Dalmatia|Dalmatia]], the southern part of the border, was similarly defined by the [[LINK|lang_en|Cretan_War_(1645–1669)|Fifth]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Ottoman–Venetian_War_(1714–1718)|Seventh Ottoman–Venetian Wars]].

The [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian–Ottoman_Wars|Ottoman wars]] instigated great demographic changes. Croats migrated towards [[LINK|lang_en|Austria|Austria]] and the present-day [[LINK|lang_en|Burgenland_Croats|Burgenland Croats]] are direct descendants of these settlers. [[CITE|154|https://webcitation.org/69Qku2uNT?Itemid=102&id=61&lang=hr&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hkd.at%2Findex.php%3Foption%3Dcom_content&view=article]] To replace the fleeing population, the Habsburgs encouraged the Christian populations of Bosnia and [[LINK|lang_en|Serbia|Serbia]] to provide military service in the Croatian Military Frontier. Serb migration into this region peaked during the [[LINK|lang_en|Great_Serb_Migrations|Great Serb Migrations]] of 1690 and 1737–39. [[CITE|205|https://books.google.com/books?id=OtW2axOSn10C]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Parliament|Croatian Parliament]] supported [[LINK|lang_en|Emperor_Charles_VI|King Charles III]]'s [[LINK|lang_en|Pragmatic_Sanction|Pragmatic Sanction]] and signed their own [[LINK|lang_en|Pragmatic_Sanction_in_1712|Pragmatic Sanction in 1712]]. Subsequently, the emperor pledged to respect all privileges and political rights of [[LINK|lang_en|Kingdom_of_Croatia_(Habsburg)|Kingdom of Croatia]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Queen_Maria_Theresa|Queen Maria Theresa]] made significant contributions to Croatian matters.

Between 1797 and 1809 the [[LINK|lang_en|First_French_Empire|First French Empire]] gradually occupied the entire eastern [[LINK|lang_en|Adriatic|Adriatic]] coastline and a substantial part of its hinterland, ending the Venetian and the Ragusan republics, establishing the [[LINK|lang_en|Illyrian_Provinces|Illyrian Provinces]]. In response the [[LINK|lang_en|Royal_Navy|Royal Navy]] started the [[LINK|lang_en|Adriatic_campaign_of_1807–1814|blockade of the Adriatic Sea]] leading to the [[LINK|lang_en|Battle_of_Lissa_(1811)|Battle of Vis]] in 1811. The Illyrian Provinces were captured by the Austrians in 1813, and absorbed by the [[LINK|lang_en|Austrian_Empire|Austrian Empire]] following the [[LINK|lang_en|Congress_of_Vienna|Congress of Vienna]] in 1815. This led to formation of the [[LINK|lang_en|Kingdom_of_Dalmatia|Kingdom of Dalmatia]] and restoration of the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Littoral|Croatian Littoral]] to the Kingdom of Croatia, now both under the same crown. [[CITE|281|https://books.google.com/books?id=ZTC3IWC_py8C]] The 1830s and 1840s saw [[LINK|lang_en|Romantic_nationalism|romantic nationalism]] inspire the [[LINK|lang_en|Illyrian_movement|Croatian National Revival]], a political and cultural campaign advocating the unity of all [[LINK|lang_en|South_Slavs|South Slavs]] in the empire. Its primary focus was the establishment of a standard language as a counterweight to [[LINK|lang_en|Hungarian_language|Hungarian]], along with the promotion of Croatian literature and culture. [[CITE|346|http://worldcat.org/issn/1332-2567]] During the [[LINK|lang_en|Hungarian_Revolution_of_1848|Hungarian Revolution of 1848]] Croatia sided with the Austrians, Ban [[LINK|lang_en|Josip_Jelačić|Josip Jelačić]] helping defeat the Hungarian forces in 1849, and ushering a period of [[LINK|lang_en|Germanization|Germanization]] policy. [[CITE|48|http://worldcat.org/issn/1845-4380]]

By the 1860s, failure of the policy became apparent, leading to the [[LINK|lang_en|Austro-Hungarian_Compromise_of_1867|Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867]] and creation of a [[LINK|lang_en|Personal_union|personal union]] between the crowns of the Austrian Empire and the [[LINK|lang_en|Kingdom_of_Hungary|Kingdom of Hungary]]. The treaty left the issue of Croatia's status to Hungary, and the status was resolved by the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian–Hungarian_Settlement|Croatian–Hungarian Settlement]] of 1868, when kingdoms of Croatia and Slavonia were united. [[CITE|72|http://h-net.org/~habsweb/sourcetexts/nagodba1.htm]] The Kingdom of Dalmatia remained under de facto Austrian control, while [[LINK|lang_en|Rijeka|Rijeka]] retained the status of [[LINK|lang_en|Corpus_separatum_(Fiume)|Corpus separatum]] introduced in 1779. [[CITE|287|http://worldcat.org/issn/1332-4853]]

After [[LINK|lang_en|Austria-Hungary|Austria-Hungary]] occupied Bosnia and Herzegovina following the [[LINK|lang_en|Treaty_of_Berlin_(1878)|1878 Treaty of Berlin]], the Croatian Military Frontier was abolished and the territory returned to Croatia in 1881, pursuant to provisions of the Croatian-Hungarian settlement. [[CITE|122|http://worldcat.org/issn/1330-349X]] [[CITE|174|http://worldcat.org/issn/0032-3241]] Renewed efforts to [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_of_Greater_Austria|reform Austria-Hungary]], entailing [[LINK|lang_en|Federalisation|federalisation]] with Croatia as a federal unit, were stopped by advent of [[LINK|lang_en|World_War_I|World War I]]. [[CITE|200|https://books.google.com/books?id=SZu0AAAAIAAJ]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|Baška_tablet|Baška tablet]], the oldest evidence of the [[LINK|lang_en|Glagolitic_alphabet|glagolitic script]]

items.text: Yugoslavia (1918–1991)

On 29 October 1918 the Croatian Parliament (*Sabor*) declared independence and decided to join the newly formed [[LINK|lang_en|State_of_Slovenes,_Croats_and_Serbs|State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs]], [[CITE|339|https://web.archive.org/web/20101202061135/http://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?sec=404]] which in turn entered into union with the [[LINK|lang_en|Kingdom_of_Serbia|Kingdom of Serbia]] on 4 December 1918 to form the [[LINK|lang_en|Kingdom_of_Serbs,_Croats,_and_Slovenes|Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes]]. [[CITE|245|https://books.google.com/books?id=2YqjfHLyyj8C]] The Croatian Parliament never ratified a decision to unite with Serbia and Montenegro. [[CITE|339|https://web.archive.org/web/20101202061135/http://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?sec=404]] The [[LINK|lang_en|Vidovdan_Constitution|1921 constitution]] defining the country as a [[LINK|lang_en|Unitary_state|unitary state]] and abolition of Croatian Parliament and historical administrative divisions effectively ended Croatian autonomy.

The new constitution was opposed by the most widely supported national political party—the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Peasant_Party|Croatian Peasant Party]] (HSS) led by [[LINK|lang_en|Stjepan_Radić|Stjepan Radić]]. [[CITE|282|http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=31497&show=clanak]]

The political situation deteriorated further as Radić was assassinated in the [[LINK|lang_en|Yugoslav_Parliament|National Assembly]] in 1928, leading to the dictatorship of King [[LINK|lang_en|Alexander_I_of_Yugoslavia|Alexander]] in January 1929. [[CITE|343|http://worldcat.org/issn/1330-0474]] The dictatorship formally ended in 1931 when the king imposed a more unitarian constitution, and changed the name of the country to Yugoslavia. [[CITE|368|https://books.google.com/books?id=yH3Hz2AXonwC]] The HSS, now led by [[LINK|lang_en|Vladko_Maček|Vladko Maček]], continued to advocate federalisation of Yugoslavia, resulting in the [[LINK|lang_en|Cvetković–Maček_Agreement|Cvetković–Maček Agreement]] of August 1939 and the autonomous [[LINK|lang_en|Banovina_of_Croatia|Banovina of Croatia]]. The Yugoslav government retained control of defence, internal security, foreign affairs, trade, and transport while other matters were left to the Croatian Sabor and a crown-appointed Ban.

In April 1941, [[LINK|lang_en|Invasion_of_Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia was occupied]] by [[LINK|lang_en|Nazi_Germany|Germany]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Kingdom_of_Italy_(1861–1946)|Italy]]. Following the invasion the territory, parts of Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the region of [[LINK|lang_en|Syrmia|Syrmia]] were incorporated into the [[LINK|lang_en|Independent_State_of_Croatia|Independent State of Croatia]] (NDH), a Nazi-backed [[LINK|lang_en|Puppet_state|puppet state]]. Parts of Dalmatia were annexed by Italy and the northern Croatian regions of [[LINK|lang_en|Baranya_(region)|Baranja]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Međimurje|Međimurje]] were annexed by Hungary. The NDH regime was led by [[LINK|lang_en|Ante_Pavelić|Ante Pavelić]] and ultranationalist [[LINK|lang_en|Ustaše|Ustaše]]. The regime introduced [[LINK|lang_en|Antisemitism|anti-semitic]] laws and conducted a campaign of [[LINK|lang_en|World_War_II_persecution_of_Serbs|ethnic cleansing and genocide against Serb]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Romani_people|Roma]] inhabitants of the NDH, exemplified by the [[LINK|lang_en|Jasenovac_concentration_camp|Jasenovac]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Stara_Gradiška_concentration_camp|Stara Gradiška]] concentration camps. [[CITE|61|http://worldcat.org/issn/0570-9008]]

It is estimated that out of 39,000 [[LINK|lang_en|Jews|Jews]] in the country only 9,000 survived; the rest were either killed or deported to Germany, both by the local authorities and the German Army itself. [[CITE|93|https://books.google.com/books?id=Tdn6FFZklkcC]] Croatian and Serbian sources disagree on the exact figures. [[CITE|115|https://books.google.com/books?id=8RdnAAAAMAAJ]]
Furthermore, a significant number of Serbs were killed by the Ustaše on the territory of the NDH during the war.

According to Midlarsky, the number of Serbs killed by the regime was at least half a million, but the figure is contradicted by [[LINK|lang_en|Bogoljub_Kočović|Bogoljub Kočović]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Vladimir_Žerjavić|Vladimir Žerjavić]]. Kočović estimated total number of Serbs killed throughout Yugoslav territory in various circumstances at 487,000, while Žerjavić put the figure at 530,000. Žerjavić indicated that 320,000 Serbs were killed in the NDH, including 82,000 killed among the Yugoslav Partisans, 23,000 killed as Axis collaborators, 25,000 victims of typhoid epidemic, 45,000 killed by Germans and 15,000 by Italians. Kočović's and Žerjavić's total Yugoslav losses are in agreement with estimates made by Mayers and Campbell of the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Census_Bureau|United States Census Bureau]]. [[CITE|197|https://books.google.com/books?id=Fz1PW_wnHYMC]] The number of Croats killed in the NDH is estimated to be approximately 200,000, either by the Croatian fascist regime, as members of the armed resistance, or as [[LINK|lang_en|Axis_powers|Axis collaborators]]. [[CITE|115|https://books.google.com/books?id=8RdnAAAAMAAJ]] Several thousand of these were killed by the Chetniks; most Croatian historians place the number of Croats killed by the Chetniks on the territory of modern-day Croatia at between 3,000 and 3,500. Croatian estimates for the number of Croats killed by Chetniks in the whole of Yugoslavia range from 18,000 to 32,000 (both combatants and civilians). [[CITE|248|http://hrcak.srce.hr/103223?lang=en]]
A resistance movement soon emerged.

On 22 June 1941, the [[LINK|lang_en|Sisak_People's_Liberation_Partisan_Detachment|1st Sisak Partisan Detachment]] was formed near [[LINK|lang_en|Sisak|Sisak]], as the first military unit formed by a resistance movement in [[LINK|lang_en|German-occupied_Europe|occupied Europe]]. This sparked the beginning of the [[LINK|lang_en|Yugoslav_Partisan|Yugoslav Partisan]] movement, a communist multi-ethnic anti-fascist resistance group led by [[LINK|lang_en|Josip_Broz_Tito|Josip Broz Tito]]. [[CITE|169|http://dzs.hr/Eng/system/first_results.htm]] The movement grew rapidly and at the [[LINK|lang_en|Tehran_Conference|Tehran Conference]] in December 1943 the Partisans gained recognition from the [[LINK|lang_en|Allies_of_World_War_II|Allies]]. [[CITE|169|http://dzs.hr/Eng/system/first_results.htm]]

With Allied support in logistics, equipment, training and air power, and with the assistance of [[LINK|lang_en|Red_Army|Soviet troops]] taking part in the 1944 [[LINK|lang_en|Belgrade_Offensive|Belgrade Offensive]], the Partisans gained control of Yugoslavia and the border regions of [[LINK|lang_en|Trieste#World_War_II_and_its_aftermath|Italy]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Carinthia_(state)#From_1920_to_the_Present|Austria]] by May 1945, during which thousands of members of the Ustaše, as well as Croat refugees, were [[LINK|lang_en|Bleiburg_repatriations|killed]] by the Yugoslav Partisans. [[CITE|169|http://dzs.hr/Eng/system/first_results.htm]]

The political aspirations of the Partisan movement were reflected in the [[LINK|lang_en|State_Anti-fascist_Council_for_the_National_Liberation_of_Croatia|State Anti-fascist Council for the National Liberation of Croatia]], which developed in 1943 as the bearer of Croatian statehood and later transformed into the Parliament of Croatia in 1945, and [[LINK|lang_en|AVNOJ|AVNOJ]] —its counterpart at the Yugoslav level. [[CITE|169|http://dzs.hr/Eng/system/first_results.htm]] [[CITE|169|http://dzs.hr/Eng/system/first_results.htm]]

After [[LINK|lang_en|World_War_II|World War II]], Croatia became a [[LINK|lang_en|Single-party|single-party]] socialist [[LINK|lang_en|Socialist_Republic_of_Croatia|federal unit]] of the [[LINK|lang_en|Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia|SFR Yugoslavia]], ruled by the [[LINK|lang_en|League_of_Communists_of_Croatia|Communists]], but enjoying a degree of autonomy within the federation. In 1967, Croatian authors and linguists published a [[LINK|lang_en|Declaration_on_the_Status_and_Name_of_the_Croatian_Standard_Language|Declaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Standard Language]] demanding greater autonomy for [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_language|Croatian language]]. [[CITE|111|http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=76413&lang=en&show=clanak]] The declaration contributed to a national movement seeking greater civil rights and decentralization of the Yugoslav economy, culminating in the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Spring|Croatian Spring]] of 1971, suppressed by Yugoslav leadership. [[CITE|179|http://jutarnji.hr/heroina-hrvatskog-proljeca/305499]] Still, the [[LINK|lang_en|1974_Yugoslav_Constitution|1974 Yugoslav Constitution]] gave increased autonomy to federal units, basically fulfilling a goal of the Croatian Spring, and providing a legal basis for independence of the federative constituents. [[CITE|225|http://ejil.org/article.php?article=1207&issue=67]]

Following the death of Yugoslav president Josip Broz Tito in 1980, the political situation in Yugoslavia deteriorated, with national tension fanned by the 1986 Serbian [[LINK|lang_en|Memorandum_of_the_Serbian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts|SANU Memorandum]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|1989_coups_in_Vojvodina,_Kosovo_and_Montenegro|1989 coups in Vojvodina, Kosovo and Montenegro]]. [[CITE|296|https://webcitation.org/69QmSYE7N?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F1989%2F01%2F12%2Fworld%2Fleaders-of-a-republic-in-yugoslavia-resign.html]] In January 1990, the Communist Party fragmented along national lines, with the Croatian [[LINK|lang_en|Political_faction|faction]] demanding a looser federation. [[CITE|334|http://worldcat.org/issn/1847-2397]] In the same year, the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_parliamentary_election,_1990|first multi-party elections]] were held in Croatia, with [[LINK|lang_en|Franjo_Tuđman|Franjo Tuđman]]'s win raising nationalist tensions further. [[CITE|14|https://webcitation.org/69Qmjvz7e?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.independent.co.uk%2Farts-entertainment%2Fobituary-franjo-tudjman-1132142.html]] Some of [[LINK|lang_en|Serbs_of_Croatia|Serbs in Croatia]] left Sabor and declared the autonomy of areas that would soon become the unrecognised [[LINK|lang_en|Republic_of_Serbian_Krajina|Republic of Serbian Krajina]], intent on achieving independence from Croatia. [[CITE|64|https://webcitation.org/69Qmswhv4?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F1990%2F10%2F02%2Fworld%2Fcroatia-s-serbs-declare-their-autonomy.html]] [[CITE|91|https://books.google.com/books?id=qmN95fFocsMC]]

caption.text: Ban [[LINK|lang_en|Josip_Jelačić|Josip Jelačić]] fought [[LINK|lang_en|Hungarian_Revolution_of_1848|Hungarians in 1848 and 1849]]

Croatian *[[LINK|lang_en|Ban_of_Croatia|ban]] * [[LINK|lang_en|Nikola_Šubić_Zrinski|Nikola Šubić Zrinski]] is honored as a national hero both in Croatia and in Hungary for his defense of [[LINK|lang_en|Siege_of_Szigetvár|Szigetvár]] against the [[LINK|lang_en|Ottoman_wars_in_Europe|invading Ottoman Turks]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|Kingdom_of_Croatia-Slavonia|Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia]] (no. 17) was autonomous kingdom within [[LINK|lang_en|Austria-Hungary|Austria-Hungary]] created in 1868 following the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian-Hungarian_Settlement|Croatian-Hungarian Settlement]]

items.text: Independence (1991–present)

As tensions rose, Croatia [[LINK|lang_en|Independence_of_Croatia|declared independence]] on 25 June 1991; however, the full implementation of declaration only came into effect on 8 October 1991. [[CITE|148|https://webcitation.org/69Wj75HVR?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F1991%2F06%2F26%2Fworld%2F2-yugoslav-states-vote-independence-to-press-demands.html]] [[CITE|251|https://webcitation.org/69Wk9bFY8?sec=2462&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sabor.hr%2FDefault.aspx%3Fart%3D20091]] In the meantime, tensions escalated into [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_War_of_Independence|overt war]] when the [[LINK|lang_en|Yugoslav_People's_Army|Yugoslav People's Army]] (JNA) and various Serb paramilitary groups attacked Croatia. [[CITE|338|https://webcitation.org/69Wkpvqwn?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F1991%2F11%2F04%2Fworld%2Farmy-rushes-to-take-a-croatian-town.html]] By the end of 1991, a high-intensity conflict fought along a wide front reduced Croatia to control of only about two-thirds of its territory. [[CITE|23|https://webcitation.org/69WlHzDK7?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F1991%2F12%2F20%2Fworld%2Fcroatia-clashes-rise-mediators-pessimistic.html]] [[CITE|81|https://webcitation.org/69WlatGyy?url=http%3A%2F%2Farticles.latimes.com%2F1991-08-01%2Fnews%2Fmn-177_1_defense-force]] The various Serb paramilitary groups then began pursuing a campaign of killing, terror and expulsion against the non-Serb population in the rebel territories, killing thousands of Croat civilians and forcing at least 170,000 from their homes. [[CITE|112|https://nytimes.com/2001/10/10/world/milosevic-indicted-again-is-charged-with-crimes-in-croatia.html]]

On 15 January 1992, Croatia gained [[LINK|lang_en|Diplomatic_recognition|diplomatic recognition]] by the [[LINK|lang_en|European_Economic_Community|European Economic Community]] members, and subsequently the United Nations. [[CITE|187|https://webcitation.org/69WmZTuSS?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F1991%2F12%2F24%2Fworld%2Fslovenia-and-croatia-get-bonn-s-nod.html]] [[CITE|274|https://webcitation.org/69WnEWOSK?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F1992%2F05%2F23%2Fworld%2F3-ex-yugoslav-republics-are-accepted-into-un.html]] The war effectively ended in August 1995 with a [[LINK|lang_en|Operation_Storm|decisive victory]] by Croatia. [[CITE|361|https://webcitation.org/69fL2KrVN?url=http%3A%2F%2Farticles.latimes.com%2F1995-08-08%2Fnews%2Fmn-32662_1_serb-refugees]] This was accompanied by the exodus of about 200,000 Serbs from the rebel territories, whose lands were subsequently settled by Croat refugees from Bosnia and Herzegovina. [[CITE|13|https://books.google.com/books?id=373cAwAAQBAJ]] The remaining occupied areas were restored to Croatia pursuant to the [[LINK|lang_en|Erdut_Agreement|Erdut Agreement]] of November 1995, with the process concluded in January 1998. [[CITE|57|https://web.archive.org/web/20130518201803/http://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/16/world/an-ethnic-morass-is-returned-to-croatia.html?ref=croatia]] Croatia became a [[LINK|lang_en|World_Trade_Organization|World Trade Organization]] (WTO) member on 30 November 2000. The country signed a [[LINK|lang_en|Stabilization_and_Association_Agreement|Stabilization and Association Agreement]] (SAA) with the European Union in October 2001. Croatia became a member of NATO on 1 April 2009, and [[LINK|lang_en|2013_enlargement_of_the_European_Union|joined]] the European Union on 1 July 2013.

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Stjepan_Radić|Stjepan Radić]], leader of the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Peasant_Party|Croatian Peasant Party]] and keen advocate of Croatian autonomy from [[LINK|lang_en|Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia|Kingdom of Yugoslavia]], at the parliamentary assembly in Dubrovnik, 1928

items.text: Geography

Croatia is located in [[LINK|lang_en|Central_Europe|Central]] and Southeast Europe, bordering [[LINK|lang_en|Hungary|Hungary]] to the northeast, Serbia to the east, [[LINK|lang_en|Bosnia_and_Herzegovina|Bosnia and Herzegovina]] to the southeast, [[LINK|lang_en|Montenegro|Montenegro]] to the southeast, the [[LINK|lang_en|Adriatic_Sea|Adriatic Sea]] to the southwest and [[LINK|lang_en|Slovenia|Slovenia]] to the northwest. It lies mostly between latitudes [[LINK|lang_en|42nd_parallel_north|42°]] and [[LINK|lang_en|47th_parallel_north|47° N]] and longitudes [[LINK|lang_en|13th_meridian_east|13°]] and [[LINK|lang_en|20th_meridian_east|20° E]]. Part of the territory in the extreme south surrounding [[LINK|lang_en|Dubrovnik|Dubrovnik]] is a [[LINK|lang_en|Practical_exclave|practical exclave]] connected to the rest of the mainland by [[LINK|lang_en|Territorial_waters|territorial waters]], but separated on land by a short coastline strip belonging to Bosnia and Herzegovina around [[LINK|lang_en|Neum|Neum]]. [[CITE|84|http://dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2010/SLJH2010.pdf]]
The territory covers 56,594 square kilometres (21,851 square miles), consisting of 56,414 square kilometres (21,782 square miles) of land and 128 square kilometres (49 square miles) of water.
It is the 127th largest country in the world.

[[CITE|149|https://cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/hr.html]] Elevation ranges from the mountains of the [[LINK|lang_en|Dinaric_Alps|Dinaric Alps]] with the highest point of the [[LINK|lang_en|Dinara|Dinara]] peak at 1,831 metres (6,007 feet) near the border with Bosnia and Herzegovina in the south [[CITE|149|https://cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/hr.html]] to the shore of the Adriatic Sea which makes up its entire southwest border. Insular Croatia consists of over [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_islands_of_Croatia|a thousand islands and islets]] varying in size, 48 of which are [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_inhabited_islands_of_Croatia|permanently inhabited]]. The largest islands are [[LINK|lang_en|Cres|Cres]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Krk|Krk]], [[CITE|149|https://cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/hr.html]] each of them having an area of around 405 square kilometres (156 square miles).

The hilly northern parts of [[LINK|lang_en|Hrvatsko_Zagorje|Hrvatsko Zagorje]] and the flat plains of Slavonia in the east (which is part of the [[LINK|lang_en|Pannonian_Basin|Pannonian Basin]]) are traversed by major rivers such as [[LINK|lang_en|Sava|Sava]], [[LINK|lang_en|Drava|Drava]], [[LINK|lang_en|Kupa|Kupa]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Danube|Danube]]. The Danube, Europe's second longest river, runs through the city of [[LINK|lang_en|Vukovar|Vukovar]] in the extreme east and forms part of the border with Serbia. The central and southern regions near the Adriatic coastline and islands consist of low mountains and forested highlands. Natural resources found in the country in quantities significant enough for production include oil, coal, bauxite, low-grade iron ore, calcium, gypsum, natural asphalt, silica, mica, clays, salt and hydropower. [[CITE|149|https://cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/hr.html]]

[[LINK|lang_en|Karst_topography|Karst topography]] makes up about half of Croatia and is especially prominent in the Dinaric Alps. [[CITE|297|http://geografija.hr/clanci/1011/rasirenost-krsa-u-hrvatskoj]] There are [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_caves_in_Croatia|a number of deep caves in Croatia]], 49 of which are deeper than 250 m (820.21 ft), 14 of them deeper than 500 m (1,640.42 ft) and three deeper than 1,000 m (3,280.84 ft). Croatia's most famous lakes are the [[LINK|lang_en|Plitvice_Lakes_National_Park|Plitvice lakes]], a system of 16 lakes with waterfalls connecting them over [[LINK|lang_en|Dolomite|dolomite]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Limestone|limestone]] cascades. The lakes are renowned for their distinctive colours, ranging from turquoise to mint green, grey or blue. [[CITE|348|https://webcitation.org/69fOQEt30?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2Ftravel%2Ffeature%2F20110617-the-best-national-parks-of-europe]]

[[LINK|lang_en|Josip_Broz_Tito|Josip Broz Tito]] led [[LINK|lang_en|SFR_Yugoslavia|SFR Yugoslavia]] from 1944 to 1980; Pictured: Tito in his hometown of [[LINK|lang_en|Kumrovec|Kumrovec]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Hrvatsko_Zagorje|Hrvatsko Zagorje]], 1961
A scene from the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_War_of_Independence|Croatian War of Independence]]

items.text: Climate

Most of Croatia has a moderately warm and rainy [[LINK|lang_en|Continental_climate|continental climate]] as defined by the [[LINK|lang_en|Köppen_climate_classification|Köppen climate classification]]. Mean monthly temperature ranges between −3 [[LINK|lang_en|Celsius|°C]] (27 [[LINK|lang_en|Fahrenheit|°F]]) (in January) and 18 °C (64 °F) (in July). The coldest parts of the country are [[LINK|lang_en|Lika|Lika]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Gorski_Kotar|Gorski Kotar]] where snowy forested climate is found at elevations above 1,200 metres (3,900 feet). The warmest areas of Croatia are at the Adriatic coast and especially in its immediate hinterland characterised by the [[LINK|lang_en|Mediterranean_climate|Mediterranean climate]], as the temperature highs are moderated by the sea. Consequently, temperature peaks are more pronounced in the continental areas—the lowest temperature of −35.5 °C (−31.9 °F) was recorded on 3 February 1919 in [[LINK|lang_en|Čakovec|Čakovec]], and the highest temperature of 42.4 °C (108.3 °F) was recorded on 5 July 1950 in [[LINK|lang_en|Karlovac|Karlovac]].
Mean annual precipitation ranges between 600 millimetres (24 inches) and 3,500 millimetres (140 inches) depending on geographic region and prevailing climate type.

The least precipitation is recorded in the outer islands ([[LINK|lang_en|Vis_(island)|Vis]], [[LINK|lang_en|Lastovo|Lastovo]], [[LINK|lang_en|Biševo|Biševo]], [[LINK|lang_en|Svetac|Svetac]]) and in the eastern parts of Slavonia; however, in the latter case, it occurs mostly during the [[LINK|lang_en|Growing_season|growing season]]. The maximum precipitation levels are observed on the Dinara mountain range and in Gorski kotar.
Prevailing winds in the interior are light to moderate northeast or southwest, and in the coastal area prevailing winds are determined by local area features.

Higher wind velocities are more often recorded in cooler months along the coast, generally as [[LINK|lang_en|Bora_(wind)|bura]] or less frequently as [[LINK|lang_en|Sirocco|sirocco]]. The sunniest parts of the country are the outer islands, Hvar and Korčula, where more than 2700 hours of sunshine are recorded per year, followed by the middle and southern Adriatic Sea area in general and northern Adriatic coast, all with more than 2000 hours of sunshine per year.

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Franjo_Tuđman|Franjo Tuđman]] was the first democratically elected [[LINK|lang_en|President_of_Croatia|President of Croatia]]

items.text: Biodiversity

Croatia can be subdivided between a number of [[LINK|lang_en|Ecoregion|ecoregions]] because of its climate and geomorphology. The country is consequently one of the richest in Europe in terms of biodiversity. There are four types of biogeographical regions in Croatia—Mediterranean along the coast and in its immediate hinterland, Alpine in most of Lika and Gorski Kotar, Pannonian along Drava and Danube, and continental in the remaining areas. One of the most significant are [[LINK|lang_en|Karst|karst]] habitats which include submerged karst, such as [[LINK|lang_en|Zrmanja|Zrmanja]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Krka_(Croatia)|Krka]] canyons and tufa barriers, as well as underground habitats.

The karst geology harbours approximately 7,000 caves and pits, some of which are habitat of the only known aquatic cave [[LINK|lang_en|Vertebrate|vertebrate]] —the [[LINK|lang_en|Olm|olm]]. Forests are also significantly present in the country, as they cover 2,490,000 hectares (6,200,000 acres) representing 44% of Croatian land surface. Other habitat types include wetlands, grasslands, bogs, fens, scrub habitats, coastal and marine habitats. [[CITE|9|http://dzzp.hr/dokumenti_upload/20120515/dzzp201205151608230.pdf]] In terms of [[LINK|lang_en|Phytogeography|phytogeography]], Croatia is a part of the [[LINK|lang_en|Boreal_Kingdom|Boreal Kingdom]] and is a part of Illyrian and Central European provinces of the [[LINK|lang_en|Circumboreal_Region|Circumboreal Region]] and the Adriatic province of the [[LINK|lang_en|Mediterranean_Region|Mediterranean Region]]. The [[LINK|lang_en|World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature|World Wide Fund for Nature]] divides Croatia between three ecoregions—Pannonian mixed forests, [[LINK|lang_en|Dinaric_Mountains_mixed_forests|Dinaric Mountains mixed forests]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Illyrian_deciduous_forests|Illyrian deciduous forests]]. [[CITE|65|http://www.dubrovnik2011.sdewes.org/venue.php]]
There are 37,000 known species in Croatia, but their actual number is estimated to be between 50,000 and 100,000.

[[CITE|9|http://dzzp.hr/dokumenti_upload/20120515/dzzp201205151608230.pdf]] The claim is supported by nearly 400 new taxa of [[LINK|lang_en|Invertebrate|invertebrates]] discovered in Croatia in the first half of the 2000s (decade) alone. [[CITE|9|http://dzzp.hr/dokumenti_upload/20120515/dzzp201205151608230.pdf]] There are more than a thousand endemic species, especially in Velebit and Biokovo mountains, Adriatic islands and karst rivers. Legislation protects 1,131 species. [[CITE|9|http://dzzp.hr/dokumenti_upload/20120515/dzzp201205151608230.pdf]] The most serious threat to species is loss and degradation of habitats. A further problem is presented by invasive alien species, especially *[[LINK|lang_en|Caulerpa_taxifolia|Caulerpa taxifolia]] * algae.

The invasive algae are regularly monitored and removed to protect the [[LINK|lang_en|Benthic_zone|benthic habitat]]. Indigenous sorts of cultivated plants and breeds of domesticated animals are also numerous. Those include five breeds of horses, five breeds of cattle, eight breeds of sheep, two breeds of pigs and a poultry breed. Even the indigenous breeds include nine endangered or critically endangered ones. [[CITE|9|http://dzzp.hr/dokumenti_upload/20120515/dzzp201205151608230.pdf]] There are 444 [[LINK|lang_en|Protected_areas_of_Croatia|protected areas of Croatia]], encompassing 9% of the country. Those include eight [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_national_parks_of_Croatia|national parks]], two strict reserves, and ten [[LINK|lang_en|Nature_park|nature parks]]. The most famous protected area and the oldest [[LINK|lang_en|National_park|national park]] in Croatia is the Plitvice Lakes National Park, a [[LINK|lang_en|World_Heritage_Sites_in_Croatia|UNESCO World Heritage Site]]. Velebit Nature Park is a part of the UNESCO [[LINK|lang_en|Man_and_the_Biosphere_Programme|Man and the Biosphere Programme]]. The strict and special reserves, as well as the national and nature parks, are managed and protected by the central government, while other protected areas are managed by counties. In 2005, the National Ecological Network was set up, as the first step in preparation of the EU accession and joining of the [[LINK|lang_en|Natura_2000|Natura 2000]] network. [[CITE|9|http://dzzp.hr/dokumenti_upload/20120515/dzzp201205151608230.pdf]]

items.text: Politics

The Republic of Croatia is a unitary state using a [[LINK|lang_en|Parliamentary_system|parliamentary system]] of governance. With the collapse of the ruling communist party in SFR Yugoslavia, Croatia organized its first [[LINK|lang_en|Multi-party_system|multi-party elections]] and adopted its [[LINK|lang_en|Constitution_of_Croatia|present constitution]] in 1990. [[CITE|95|https://nytimes.com/1990/05/09/world/evolution-in-europe-conservatives-win-in-croatia.html?ref=croatia]] It [[LINK|lang_en|Declaration_of_independence|declared independence]] on 8 October 1991 which led to the [[LINK|lang_en|Breakup_of_Yugoslavia|break-up of Yugoslavia]] and countries international recognition by the United Nations in 1992. [[CITE|251|https://webcitation.org/69Wk9bFY8?sec=2462&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sabor.hr%2FDefault.aspx%3Fart%3D20091]] [[CITE|274|https://webcitation.org/69WnEWOSK?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F1992%2F05%2F23%2Fworld%2F3-ex-yugoslav-republics-are-accepted-into-un.html]] Under its 1990 constitution, Croatia operated a [[LINK|lang_en|Semi-presidential_system|semi-presidential system]] until 2000 when it switched to a parliamentary system. [[CITE|121|http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1097128.stm]] Government powers in Croatia are divided into legislative, executive and judiciary powers. [[CITE|158|http://vlada.hr/en/about_croatia/information/political_structure]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|President_of_Croatia|President of the Republic]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_language|Croatian]]: *Predsjednik Republike*) is the [[LINK|lang_en|Head_of_state|head of state]], directly elected to a five-year term and is limited by the Constitution to a maximum of two terms. In addition to being the [[LINK|lang_en|Commander_in_chief|commander in chief]] of the armed forces, the president has the procedural duty of appointing the prime minister with the consent of the parliament, and has some influence on foreign policy. [[CITE|158|http://vlada.hr/en/about_croatia/information/political_structure]] The most recent presidential elections were held on 11 January 2015, when [[LINK|lang_en|Kolinda_Grabar-Kitarović|Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović]] won. She took the [[LINK|lang_en|Oath_of_office|oath of office]] on 15 February 2015. [[CITE|275|http://predsjednik.hr/PRESIDENT]] The [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Government|government]] is headed by the [[LINK|lang_en|Prime_Minister_of_Croatia|Prime Minister]], who has four deputy prime ministers and 16 ministers in charge of particular sectors of activity. [[CITE|332|http://vlada.hr/en/naslovnica/o_vladi_rh/clanovi_vlade]] As the [[LINK|lang_en|Executive_(government)|executive branch]], it is responsible for proposing legislation and a budget, executing the laws, and guiding the foreign and internal policies of the republic. The government is seated at [[LINK|lang_en|Banski_dvori|Banski dvori]] in Zagreb. [[CITE|158|http://vlada.hr/en/about_croatia/information/political_structure]] Since 19 October 2016, Croatian Prime Minister has been [[LINK|lang_en|Andrej_Plenković|Andrej Plenković]].

The parliament (*Sabor*) is a [[LINK|lang_en|Unicameral|unicameral]] legislative body. A second [[LINK|lang_en|Chambers_of_parliament|chamber]], the *House of Counties*, set up in 1993 pursuant to the 1990 Constitution, was abolished in 2001. The number of Sabor members can vary from 100 to 160; they are all elected by popular vote to serve four-year terms. The sessions of the Sabor take place from 15 January to 15 July, and from 15 September to 15 December. [[CITE|362|http://sabor.hr/Default.aspx?sec=713]] The two largest political parties in Croatia are the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Democratic_Union|Croatian Democratic Union]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Social_Democratic_Party_of_Croatia|Social Democratic Party of Croatia]]. [[CITE|18|http://sabor.hr/Default.aspx?sec=776]]

caption.text: Köppen climate types of Croatia

items.text: Law and judicial system

Croatia has a [[LINK|lang_en|Civil_law_(legal_system)|civil law]] legal system in which law arises primarily from written statutes, with judges serving merely as implementers, and not creators of law. Its development was largely influenced by German and Austrian legal systems. Croatian law is divided into two principal areas – [[LINK|lang_en|Civil_law_(Civil_law)|private]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Public_law|public law]]. By the time [[LINK|lang_en|Accession_of_Croatia_to_the_European_Union|EU accession negotiations]] were completed on 30 June 2010, Croatian legislation was fully harmonised with the [[LINK|lang_en|Community_acquis|Community acquis]]. [[CITE|68|http://www.delhrv.ec.europa.eu/?content=62&lang=en]] The main law in the county is the [[LINK|lang_en|Constitution_of_Croatia|Constitution]] adopted on December 22, 1990.

The main national courts are the [[LINK|lang_en|Constitutional_Court_of_Croatia|Constitutional Court]], which oversees violations of the Constitution, and the [[LINK|lang_en|Supreme_Court_of_Croatia|Supreme Court]], which is the highest court of appeal. In addition, there are also [[LINK|lang_en|County_Court|County]], Municipal, Misdemeanor, Commercial, and Administrative courts. [[CITE|89|http://vsrh.hr/EasyWeb.asp?pcpid=31]] Cases falling within judicial jurisdiction are in the first instance decided by a single professional judge, while appeals are deliberated in mixed tribunals of professional judges. Lay magistrates also participate in trials. [[CITE|106|http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2013_03_28_473.html]] [[LINK|lang_en|State's_Attorney_Office_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia|State's Attorney Office]] is the judicial body constituted of public prosecutors that is empowered to instigate prosecution of perpetrators of offences.

Law enforcement agencies are organised under the authority of the [[LINK|lang_en|Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Croatia)|Ministry of the Interior]] which consist primarily of the national police force. Croatia's security service is the [[LINK|lang_en|Security_and_Intelligence_Agency|Security and Intelligence Agency]] (SOA).
Administrative divisions

Croatia was first subdivided into counties in the [[LINK|lang_en|Middle_Ages|Middle Ages]]. [[CITE|131|http://historiografija.hr/hz/1952/HZ_5_11_MANDIC.pdf]] The divisions changed over time to reflect losses of territory to Ottoman conquest and subsequent liberation of the same territory, changes of political status of Dalmatia, Dubrovnik and [[LINK|lang_en|Istria|Istria]]. Traditional division of the country into counties was abolished in the 1920s, when the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes and subsequent Kingdom of Yugoslavia introduced [[LINK|lang_en|Oblast|oblasts]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Subdivisions_of_the_Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia|banovinas]] respectively.

Communist-ruled Croatia, as a constituent part of post-World War II Yugoslavia, abolished earlier divisions and introduced municipalities, subdividing Croatia into approximately one hundred municipalities.

Counties were reintroduced in 1992 legislation, significantly altered in terms of territory relative to the pre-1920s subdivisions: In 1918, the [[LINK|lang_en|Transleithania|Transleithanian]] part of Croatia was divided into eight counties with their seats in [[LINK|lang_en|Bjelovar|Bjelovar]], [[LINK|lang_en|Gospić|Gospić]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ogulin|Ogulin]], [[LINK|lang_en|Požega,_Croatia|Požega]], Vukovar, [[LINK|lang_en|Varaždin|Varaždin]], [[LINK|lang_en|Osijek|Osijek]] and Zagreb, and the 1992 legislation established 14 counties in the same territory. [[CITE|213|http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/1992_12_90_2333.html]]

Since the counties were re-established in 1992, Croatia is divided into 20 [[LINK|lang_en|Counties_of_Croatia|counties]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Zagreb|capital city of Zagreb]], the latter having the authority and legal status of a county and a city at the same time. Borders of the counties changed in some instances since, with the latest revision taking place in 2006. The counties subdivide into 127 [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_cities_in_Croatia|cities]] and 429 [[LINK|lang_en|Municipalities_of_Croatia|municipalities]]. [[CITE|262|http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2006_07_86_2045.html]] [[LINK|lang_en|Nomenclature_of_Territorial_Units_for_Statistics|Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics]] (NUTS) [[LINK|lang_en|NUTS_of_Croatia|division of Croatia]] is performed in several tiers. NUTS 1 level places the entire country in a single unit, while there are three NUTS 2 regions. Those are Northwest Croatia, Central and Eastern (Pannonian) Croatia and Adriatic Croatia. The latter encompasses all the counties along the Adriatic coast. The Northwest Croatia includes the city of Zagreb, Zagreb, Krapina-Zagorje, Varaždin, Koprivnica-Križevci and Međimurje counties, and the Central and Eastern (Pannonian) Croatia includes the remaining areas—Bjelovar-Bilogora, Virovitica-Podravina, Požega-Slavonia, Brod-Posavina, Osijek-Baranja, Vukovar-Syrmia, Karlovac and Sisak-Moslavina counties. Individual counties and the city of Zagreb also represent NUTS 3 level subdivision units in Croatia. The NUTS [[LINK|lang_en|Local_administrative_unit|Local administrative unit]] divisions are two-tiered. LAU 1 divisions match the counties and the city of Zagreb in effect making those the same as NUTS 3 units, while LAU 2 subdivisions correspond to the cities and municipalities of Croatia. [[CITE|299|http://coe.int/t/dg4/cultureheritage/heritage/cemat/confminist1-15/15eCEMAT_National_Report_Croatia_2010_HR.pdf]]

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Bora_(wind)|Bora]] is a dry, cold wind which blows from the mainland out to sea, whose gusts can reach hurricane strength, particularly in the channel below [[LINK|lang_en|Velebit|Velebit]], e.g. in the town of [[LINK|lang_en|Senj|Senj]]
Cliffs in [[LINK|lang_en|Telašćica|Telašćica]] Nature Park

[[LINK|lang_en|St._Mark's_Square,_Zagreb|St. Mark's Square in Zagreb]] – *Left-to-right*: [[LINK|lang_en|Banski_dvori|Banski dvori]] official residence of the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Government|Croatian Government]], [[LINK|lang_en|St._Mark's_Church,_Zagreb|St. Mark's Church]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Parliament|Croatian Parliament]]
Seat of the [[LINK|lang_en|Constitutional_Court_of_Croatia|Constitutional Court]] on the [[LINK|lang_en|St._Mark's_Square,_Zagreb|St. Mark's Square, Zagreb]]
