items.text: Foreign relations
Croatia has established diplomatic relations with 181 countries.

[[CITE|317|http://tportal.hr/vijesti/svijet/126015/Vatikan-nije-medu-prvima-priznao-Hrvatsku.html]] It's considered a [[LINK|lang_en|Middle_power|middle power]] in international affairs. [[CITE|335|https://hrcak.srce.hr/file/155701]] [[CITE|352|https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/hu/Documents/about-deloitte/HU-CETop-500-finalreport-2016.pdf]] [[CITE|11|http://croatianhistory.net/etf/etfss.html]] [[CITE|35|https://books.google.com/books/about/Croatia.html?id=HJexhW3C0TIC]] As of 2009, Croatia maintains a network of 51 embassies, 24 consulates and eight permanent diplomatic missions abroad. Furthermore, there are 52 foreign embassies and 69 [[LINK|lang_en|Consul_(representative)|consulates]] in the Republic of Croatia in addition to offices of international organisations such as the [[LINK|lang_en|European_Bank_for_Reconstruction_and_Development|European Bank for Reconstruction and Development]], [[LINK|lang_en|International_Organization_for_Migration|International Organization for Migration]], OSCE, [[LINK|lang_en|World_Bank|World Bank]], [[LINK|lang_en|World_Health_Organization|World Health Organization]] (WHO), [[LINK|lang_en|International_Criminal_Tribunal_for_the_former_Yugoslavia|International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia]] (ICTY), [[LINK|lang_en|United_Nations_Development_Programme|United Nations Development Programme]], [[LINK|lang_en|United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees|United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]] and [[LINK|lang_en|UNICEF|UNICEF]]. [[CITE|76|http://mfa.hr/MVP.asp?pcpid=1614]] In 2009, the Croatian [[LINK|lang_en|Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_and_European_Integration_(Croatia)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration]] employed 1,381 personnel and expended 648.2 million kuna (€86.4 million). [[CITE|103|http://revizija.hr/izvjesca/2011-rr-2009-poseban-dio/03_ministarstvo_vanjskih_poslova_i_europskih_integracija.pdf]] Stated aims of Croatian foreign policy include enhancing relations with neighbouring countries, developing international co-operation and promotion of the Croatian economy and Croatia itself. [[CITE|124|http://un.mfa.hr/?mh=151&mv=840]]

Since 2003, Croatian foreign policy has focused on achieving the strategic goal of becoming a [[LINK|lang_en|Member_state_of_the_European_Union|member state of the European Union]] (EU). [[CITE|193|https://webcitation.org/68ocR483H?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nacional.hr%2Fclanak%2F21036%2Fmesiceva-podrska-un-u-blokira-ulazak-hrvatske-u-nato]] [[CITE|285|http://sabor.hr/Default.aspx?art=1680]] In December 2011, Croatia completed the EU accession negotiations and signed [[LINK|lang_en|Treaty_of_Accession_2011|an EU accession treaty]] on 9 December 2011. [[CITE|328|http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?aged=0&format=HTML&guiLanguage=en&language=EN&reference=IP%2F11%2F824]] [[CITE|19|http://europa.eu/news/external-relations/2011/03/20110302_en.htm]] Croatia joined the [[LINK|lang_en|European_Union|European Union]] on 1 July 2013 marking the end of a process started in 2001 by signing of the [[LINK|lang_en|Stabilisation_and_Association_Process|Stabilisation and Association Agreement]] and Croatian application for the EU membership in 2003. [[CITE|59|https://nytimes.com/2011/06/11/world/europe/11iht-croatia11.html]] A recurring obstacle to the negotiations was Croatia's ICTY co-operation record and Slovenian blocking of the negotiations because of [[LINK|lang_en|Croatia–Slovenia_border_disputes|Croatia–Slovenia border disputes]]. [[CITE|96|http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4337777.stm]] [[CITE|132|http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8250441.stm]] The latter was resolved through an Arbitration Agreement of 4 November 2009, approved by national parliaments and a referendum in Slovenia. [[CITE|182|https://nytimes.com/2010/06/07/world/europe/07iht-slovenia.html]]

Another strategic Croatian foreign policy goal for the 2000s was [[LINK|lang_en|Croatia–NATO_relations|NATO membership]]. [[CITE|193|https://webcitation.org/68ocR483H?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nacional.hr%2Fclanak%2F21036%2Fmesiceva-podrska-un-u-blokira-ulazak-hrvatske-u-nato]] [[CITE|285|http://sabor.hr/Default.aspx?art=1680]] Croatia was included in the [[LINK|lang_en|Partnership_for_Peace|Partnership for Peace]] in 2000, invited to [[LINK|lang_en|NATO|NATO]] membership in 2008 and formally joined the alliance on 1 April 2009. [[CITE|219|https://nytimes.com/2008/04/05/world/europe/05cnd-prexy.html]] [[CITE|266|http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7977332.stm]] Croatia became a member of the [[LINK|lang_en|United_Nations_Security_Council|United Nations Security Council]] for the 2008–2009 term, assuming presidency in December 2008. [[CITE|289|http://mvpei.hr/mvp.asp?pcpid=2531]] The country is preparing to join the [[LINK|lang_en|Schengen_Area|Schengen Area]]. [[CITE|356|http://worldcat.org/issn/1334-4366]]
Military

The Croatian Armed Forces (CAF) consist of the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Army|Army]], [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Navy|Navy]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Air_Force_and_Air_Defence|Air Force]] branches in addition to the Education and Training Command and Support Command. The CAF is headed by the [[LINK|lang_en|General_Staff_of_the_Armed_Forces_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia|General Staff]], which reports to the [[LINK|lang_en|Ministry_of_Defence_(Croatia)|Defence Minister]], who in turn reports to the President of Croatia. According to the constitution, the President is [[LINK|lang_en|Commander-in-chief|commander-in-chief]] of the armed forces and in case of immediate threat during wartime he issues orders directly to the General Staff. [[CITE|342|http://osrh.hr/prikaz_en.asp?idi=100&kati=2]]
Following the 1991–95 war defence spending and CAF size have been in constant decline.
As of 2005 military spending was an estimated 2.39% of the country's GDP, which placed Croatia 64th in a ranking of all countries.
[[CITE|149|https://cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/hr.html]] Since 2005 the budget was kept below 2% of GDP, down from the record high of 11.1% in 1994.

[[CITE|45|http://milexdata.sipri.org]] Traditionally relying on a large number of conscripts, CAF also went through a period of reforms focused on downsizing, restructuring and [[LINK|lang_en|Professionalisation|professionalisation]] in the years prior to [[LINK|lang_en|Accession_of_Croatia_to_NATO|Croatia's accession to NATO]] in April 2009. According to a presidential decree issued in 2006 the CAF is set to employ 18,100 active duty military personnel, 3,000 civilians and 2,000 voluntary conscripts between the ages of 18 and 30 in peacetime. [[CITE|342|http://osrh.hr/prikaz_en.asp?idi=100&kati=2]]
Compulsory conscription was abolished in January 2008.

[[CITE|149|https://cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/hr.html]] Until 2008 military service was compulsory for men at age 18 and conscripts served six-month tours of duty, reduced in 2001 from the earlier scheme of nine-month conscription tours.
Conscientious objectors could instead opt for an eight-month civilian service.

[[CITE|77|http://monitor.hr/clanci/vojni-rok-u-hrvatskoj-kraci-nego-drugdje-u-europi-i-nato-u/11191]] As of April 2011 the Croatian military had 120 members stationed in foreign countries as part of United Nations-led international peacekeeping forces, including 95 serving as part of the [[LINK|lang_en|United_Nations_Disengagement_Observer_Force_Zone|UNDOF]] in the [[LINK|lang_en|Golan_Heights|Golan Heights]]. [[CITE|155|http://morh.hr/hr/smos-broj-pripadnika-osrh-u-mirovnim-misijama-un-a.html]] As of 2011 an additional 350 troops serve as part of the NATO-led [[LINK|lang_en|International_Security_Assistance_Force|ISAF]] force in Afghanistan and another 20 with the [[LINK|lang_en|Kosovo_Force|KFOR]] in Kosovo. [[CITE|214|http://ezadar.hr/clanak/hrvatska-salje-jos-vojnika-u-afganistan]] [[CITE|259|http://index.hr/vijesti/clanak/kosorica-u-sluzbenom-posjetu-kosovu/567980.aspx]]

Croatia also has a significant [[LINK|lang_en|Military_industry|military industry]] sector which exported around US$120 million worth of military equipment and armament in 2010. [[CITE|307|http://vjesnik.hr/Article.aspx?ID=12C86DFB-1818-459C-B8E6-687AFABF57A2]] Croatian-made weapons and vehicles used by CAF include the standard sidearm [[LINK|lang_en|HS2000|HS2000]] manufactured by [[LINK|lang_en|HS_Produkt|HS Produkt]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|M-84D|M-84D]] battle tank designed by the [[LINK|lang_en|Đuro_Đaković_(factory)|Đuro Đaković factory]]. Uniforms and helmets worn by CAF soldiers are also locally produced and successfully marketed to other countries. [[CITE|307|http://vjesnik.hr/Article.aspx?ID=12C86DFB-1818-459C-B8E6-687AFABF57A2]]
Economy
Croatia is classified as a high-income economy by the United Nations.

[[CITE|29|http://worldcat.org/issn/0473-0992]] [[LINK|lang_en|International_Monetary_Fund|International Monetary Fund]] data projects that Croatian [[LINK|lang_en|Nominal_GDP|nominal GDP]] stands at $52 billion, or $12,405 per capita for year 2017, while [[LINK|lang_en|Purchasing_power_parity|purchasing power parity]] GDP stands at $97 billion, or $23,171 per capita. [[CITE|104|https://imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2017/01/weodata/weorept.aspx?a=&br=1&c=960&ds=.&ey=2022&grp=0&pr.x=62&pr.y=12&s=NGDPD%2CNGDPDPC%2CPPPGDP%2CPPPPC&scsm=1&sort=country&ssd=1&sy=2015]] According to [[LINK|lang_en|Eurostat|Eurostat]] data, Croatian PPS GDP per capita stood at 61% of the EU average in 2012. [[CITE|87|http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/cache/ITY_PUBLIC/2-19062013-BP/EN/2-19062013-BP-EN.PDF]]
Real GDP growth in 2007 was 6.0 per cent.

[[CITE|129|http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/portal/page?_dad=portal&_pageid=1996%2C39140985&_schema=PORTAL&language=en&product=STRIND_ECOBAC&root=STRIND_ECOBAC%2Fecobac%2Feb012&screen=detailref]] The average net salary of a Croatian worker in January 2017 was 5,895 [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_kuna|HRK]] per month, and the average gross salary was 7,911 HRK per month. [[CITE|171|http://dzs.hr/default_e.htm]] As of February 2017, registered unemployment rate in Croatia was 15.3%. [[CITE|29|http://worldcat.org/issn/0473-0992]]

In 2010, economic output was dominated by the [[LINK|lang_en|Service_sector|service sector]] which accounted for 66% of GDP, followed by the [[LINK|lang_en|Industrial_sector|industrial sector]] with 27.2% and agriculture accounting for 6.8% of GDP. [[CITE|29|http://worldcat.org/issn/0473-0992]] According to 2004 data, 2.7% of the workforce were employed in agriculture, 32.8% by industry and 64.5% in services. [[CITE|149|https://cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/hr.html]] [[CITE|29|http://worldcat.org/issn/0473-0992]] The industrial sector is dominated by shipbuilding, food processing, pharmaceuticals, information technology, biochemical and timber industry. In 2010, Croatian exports were valued at 64.9 billion kuna (€8.65 billion) with 110.3 billion kuna (€14.7 billion) worth of imports. The largest [[LINK|lang_en|International_trade|trading partner]] is rest of the European Union. [[CITE|29|http://worldcat.org/issn/0473-0992]] More than half of Croatia's trade is with other European Union member states. [[CITE|29|http://worldcat.org/issn/0473-0992]]

[[LINK|lang_en|Privatization|Privatization]] and the drive toward a [[LINK|lang_en|Market_economy|market economy]] had barely begun under the new Croatian Government when war broke out in 1991. As a result of the war, the economic infrastructure sustained massive damage, particularly the revenue-rich tourism industry. From 1989 to 1993, the GDP fell 40.5%. The Croatian state still controls a significant part of the economy, with government expenditures accounting for as much as 40% of GDP. [[CITE|1|http://m.state.gov/md3166.htm]] A backlogged judiciary system, combined with inefficient [[LINK|lang_en|Public_administration|public administration]], especially on issues of land ownership and corruption, are particular concerns. In the 2015 [[LINK|lang_en|Corruption_Perceptions_Index|Corruption Perceptions Index]], published by [[LINK|lang_en|Transparency_International|Transparency International]], the country is ranked joint 50th with a score of 51, where zero denotes "highly corrupt" and 100 "very clean". [[CITE|27|http://transparency.org/cpi2015/results#results-table]] In June 2013, the national debt stood at 59.5% of the nation's GDP. [[CITE|54|http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=26644&show=clanak]]
Tourism

[[LINK|lang_en|Tourism_in_Croatia|Tourism]] dominates the Croatian service sector and accounts for up to 20% of Croatian GDP. Annual tourist industry income for 2014 was estimated at €7.4 billion. [[CITE|54|http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=26644&show=clanak]] Its positive effects are felt throughout the economy of Croatia in terms of increased business volume observed in retail business, processing industry orders and summer seasonal employment. The industry is considered an export business, because it significantly reduces the country's external trade imbalance. [[CITE|54|http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=26644&show=clanak]] Since the conclusion of the Croatian War of Independence, the tourist industry has grown rapidly, recording a fourfold rise in tourist numbers, with more than 11 million tourists each year. The most numerous are tourists from Germany, Slovenia, Austria, Italy and the [[LINK|lang_en|Czech_Republic|Czech Republic]] as well as Croatia itself. Length of a tourist stay in Croatia averages 4.9 days. [[CITE|54|http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=26644&show=clanak]]
The bulk of the tourist industry is concentrated along the Adriatic Sea coast.

[[LINK|lang_en|Opatija|Opatija]] was the first holiday resort since the middle of the 19th century. By the 1890s, it became one of the most significant European health resorts. [[CITE|54|http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=26644&show=clanak]] Later a number of resorts sprang up along the coast and islands, offering services ranging from [[LINK|lang_en|Mass_tourism|mass tourism]] to catering and various niche markets, the most significant being [[LINK|lang_en|Nautical_tourism|nautical tourism]], as there are numerous marinas with more than 16 thousand berths, [[LINK|lang_en|Cultural_tourism|cultural tourism]] relying on appeal of medieval coastal cities and numerous cultural events taking place during the summer. Inland areas offer mountain resorts, [[LINK|lang_en|Agrotourism|agrotourism]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Spa|spas]]. Zagreb is also a significant tourist destination, rivalling major coastal cities and resorts. [[CITE|54|http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=26644&show=clanak]]

Croatia has unpolluted marine areas reflected through numerous nature reserves and 116 [[LINK|lang_en|Blue_Flag_beach|Blue Flag beaches]]. [[CITE|54|http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=26644&show=clanak]] Croatia is ranked as the 18th most popular tourist destination in the world. [[CITE|100|http://unwto.org/facts/eng/pdf/barometer/UNWTO_Barom07_3_en.pdf]] About 15% of these visitors (over one million per year) are involved with [[LINK|lang_en|Naturism|naturism]], an industry for which Croatia is world-famous. It was also the first European country to develop commercial naturist resorts.
Infrastructure

The highlight of Croatia's recent infrastructure developments is its rapidly developed [[LINK|lang_en|Motorways_in_Croatia|motorway network]], largely built in the late 1990s and especially in the 2000s (decade). By September 2011, Croatia had completed more than 1,100 kilometres (680 miles) of motorways, connecting Zagreb to most other regions and following various [[LINK|lang_en|International_E-road_network|European routes]] and four [[LINK|lang_en|Pan-European_corridors|Pan-European corridors]]. [[CITE|125|http://hrcak.srce.hr/file/6570]] [[CITE|201|http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2007_07_77_2443.html]] [[CITE|243|http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2009_01_13_296.html]] The busiest motorways are the [[LINK|lang_en|A1_(Croatia)|A1]], connecting Zagreb to Split and the [[LINK|lang_en|A3_(Croatia)|A3]], passing east–west through northwest Croatia and Slavonia. [[CITE|-1|http://hrvatske-ceste.hr/WEB-%20Legislativa/brojenje-prometa/CroDig2009.pdf]] A widespread network of [[LINK|lang_en|State_roads_in_Croatia|state roads in Croatia]] acts as motorway [[LINK|lang_en|Feeder_line_(network)|feeder roads]] while connecting all major settlements in the country. The high quality and safety levels of the Croatian motorway network were tested and confirmed by several EuroTAP and EuroTest programs.

Croatia has an [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_railways_in_Croatia|extensive rail network]] spanning 2,722 kilometres (1,691 miles), including 984 kilometres (611 miles) of electrified railways and 254 kilometres (158 miles) of double track railways. The most significant railways in Croatia are found within the Pan-European transport corridors Vb and X connecting Rijeka to Budapest and Ljubljana to Belgrade, both via Zagreb. [[CITE|125|http://hrcak.srce.hr/file/6570]] All rail services are operated by [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Railways|Croatian Railways]].

There are [[LINK|lang_en|International_airport|international airports]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Zagreb_International_Airport|Zagreb]], [[LINK|lang_en|Zadar_Airport|Zadar]], [[LINK|lang_en|Split_Airport|Split]], [[LINK|lang_en|Dubrovnik_Airport|Dubrovnik]], [[LINK|lang_en|Rijeka_Airport|Rijeka]], [[LINK|lang_en|Osijek_Airport|Osijek]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Pula_Airport|Pula]]. [[CITE|357|http://mppi.hr/default.aspx?id=675]] The largest and busiest is Franjo Tuđman Airport. [[CITE|153|http://worldcat.org/issn/1330-0644]] As of January 2011, Croatia complies with [[LINK|lang_en|International_Civil_Aviation_Organization|International Civil Aviation Organization]] aviation safety standards and the [[LINK|lang_en|Federal_Aviation_Administration|Federal Aviation Administration]] upgraded it to Category 1 rating. [[CITE|153|http://worldcat.org/issn/1330-0644]]

The busiest cargo [[LINK|lang_en|Seaport|seaport]] in Croatia is the [[LINK|lang_en|Port_of_Rijeka|Port of Rijeka]] and the busiest passenger ports are [[LINK|lang_en|Port_of_Split|Split]] and Zadar. [[CITE|70|http://go.worldbank.org/V9N60RX7L0]] [[CITE|113|http://mppi.hr/default.aspx?id=480]] In addition to those, a large number of minor ports serve an extensive system of ferries connecting numerous islands and coastal cities in addition to ferry lines to several cities in Italy. [[CITE|211|http://agencija-zolpp.hr/Brodskelinije/tabid/1267/Default.aspx]] The largest river port is Vukovar, located on the Danube, representing the nation's outlet to the Pan-European transport corridor VII. [[CITE|125|http://hrcak.srce.hr/file/6570]] [[CITE|263|http://mppi.hr/default.aspx?id=890]]
There are 610 kilometres (380 miles) of crude oil pipelines in Croatia, connecting the Port of Rijeka oil terminal with refineries in Rijeka and Sisak, as well as several transhipment terminals.
The system has a capacity of 20 million tonnes per year.

[[CITE|294|http://janaf.hr/index.php?lang=en&option=sustav]] The natural gas transportation system comprises 2,113 kilometres (1,313 miles) of trunk and regional natural gas pipelines, and more than 300 associated structures, connecting production rigs, the Okoli natural gas storage facility, 27 end-users and 37 distribution systems.
[[CITE|319|http://plinacro.hr/default.aspx?id=264]]
Croatian production of energy sources covers 85% of nationwide natural gas demand and 19% of oil demand.

In 2008, 47.6% of Croatia's primary energy production structure comprised use of natural gas (47.7%), crude oil (18.0%), fuel wood (8.4%), hydro power (25.4%) and other renewable energy sources (0.5%).
In 2009, net total electrical power production in Croatia reached 12,725 GWh and Croatia imported 28.5% of its electric power energy needs.

[[CITE|84|http://dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2010/SLJH2010.pdf]] The bulk of Croatian imports are supplied by the [[LINK|lang_en|Krško_Nuclear_Power_Plant|Krško Nuclear Power Plant]], 50% owned by [[LINK|lang_en|Hrvatska_elektroprivreda|Hrvatska elektroprivreda]], providing 15% of Croatia's electricity. [[CITE|349|http://eubusiness.com/news-eu/japan-disaster.9bc]]
Demographics

With its estimated population of 4,19 million in 2016, Croatia [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_countries_by_population|ranks 125th by population]] in the world. Its [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_population_density|population density]] stands at 75.9 inhabitants per square kilometre. The overall [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy|life expectancy in Croatia]] at birth was 78 years in 2012. [[CITE|369|http://gamapserver.who.int/gho/interactive_charts/mbd/life_expectancy/atlas.html]] The [[LINK|lang_en|Total_fertility_rate|total fertility rate]] of 1.5 children per mother, is one of the [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_fertility_rate|lowest in the world]]. Since 1991, Croatia's [[LINK|lang_en|Death_rate|death rate]] has continuously exceeded its [[LINK|lang_en|Birth_rate|birth rate]]. [[CITE|84|http://dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2010/SLJH2010.pdf]] Since the late 1990s, there has been a positive net migration into Croatia, reaching a level of more than 7,000 net immigrants in 2006. [[CITE|33|http://limun.hr/main.aspx?NadID=178578&id=178599]] According to the 2013 United Nations report, 17.6% of Croatia's population were foreign-born immigrants. [[CITE|196|https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Illyrians.html?id=4Nv6SPRKqs8C]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Bureau_of_Statistics|Croatian Bureau of Statistics]] forecast that the population may shrink to 3.1 million by 2051, depending on actual birth rate and the level of net migration. [[CITE|94|http://dzs.hr/Hrv/important/Notices/projekcije_stanovnistva_2004-2051.pdf]] The population of Croatia rose steadily from 2.1 million in 1857 until 1991, when it peaked at 4.7 million, with exception of censuses taken in 1921 and 1948, i.e. following two world wars. [[CITE|84|http://dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2010/SLJH2010.pdf]] The natural growth rate of the population is currently negative [[CITE|149|https://cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/hr.html]] with the [[LINK|lang_en|Demographic_transition|demographic transition]] completed in the 1970s. [[CITE|196|https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Illyrians.html?id=4Nv6SPRKqs8C]] In recent years, the Croatian government has been pressured each year to add 40% to work permit quotas for foreign workers. [[CITE|196|https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Illyrians.html?id=4Nv6SPRKqs8C]] In accordance with its immigration policy, Croatia is trying to entice emigrants to return. [[CITE|196|https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Illyrians.html?id=4Nv6SPRKqs8C]]
The population decrease was also a result of the Croatian War of Independence.
During the war, large sections of the population were displaced and emigration increased.
In 1991, in predominantly Serb areas, more than 400,000 Croats and other non-Serbs were either removed from their homes by the Croatian Serb forces or fled the violence.

[[CITE|196|https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Illyrians.html?id=4Nv6SPRKqs8C]] During the final days of the war in 1995, more than 120,000 Serbs, [[CITE|196|https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Illyrians.html?id=4Nv6SPRKqs8C]] and perhaps as many as 200,000, [[CITE|196|https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Illyrians.html?id=4Nv6SPRKqs8C]] fled the country before arrival of Croatian forces during Operation Storm. Within a decade following the end of the war, only 117,000 Serb refugees returned out of 300,000 displaced during the entire war. [[CITE|16|http://osce.org/zagreb/15985]] Most of Croatia's remaining Serbs never lived in areas occupied in the Croatian War of Independence. Serbs have been only partially re-settled in the regions they previously inhabited while some of the settlements previously inhabited by Serbs were settled by Croat refugees from Bosnia and Herzegovina, mostly from [[LINK|lang_en|Republika_Srpska|Republika Srpska]]. [[CITE|47|http://index.hr/vijesti/clanak/savez-udruga-hrvataiz-bih-izabrao-novo-celnistvo/145769.aspx]] [[CITE|107|http://predsjednik.hr/29062010]]

Croatia is inhabited mostly by Croats (90.4%) and is ethnically the most [[LINK|lang_en|Homogeneity_and_heterogeneity|homogeneous]] of the six countries of former Yugoslavia. Minority groups include Serbs (4.4%), [[LINK|lang_en|Bosniaks|Bosniaks]], [[LINK|lang_en|Hungarians|Hungarians]], Italians, [[LINK|lang_en|Slovenes|Slovenes]], [[LINK|lang_en|Germans|Germans]], [[LINK|lang_en|Czechs|Czechs]], Romani people and others (5.9%). [[CITE|4|http://dzs.hr/Eng/censuses/census2011/results/htm/E01_01_04/e01_01_04_RH.html]]
Religion
Croatia has no official religion.

[[LINK|lang_en|Freedom_of_religion|Freedom of religion]] is a right defined by the Constitution which also defines all [[LINK|lang_en|Religious_denomination|religious communities]] as [[LINK|lang_en|Separation_of_church_and_state|equal in front of the law and separated from the state]].

According to the 2011 census, 91.36% of Croatians identify as Christian; of these, Roman Catholics make up the largest group, accounting for 86.28% of the population, after which follows [[LINK|lang_en|Eastern_Orthodoxy|Eastern Orthodoxy]] (4.44%), [[LINK|lang_en|Protestantism|Protestantism]] (0.34%) and other Christianity (0.30%). Second largest religion is [[LINK|lang_en|Islam|Islam]] (1.47%). 4.57% of the population describes themselves as non-religious. [[CITE|199|http://dzs.hr/Eng/censuses/census2011/results/htm/E01_01_10/e01_01_10_RH.html]]

In the [[LINK|lang_en|Eurostat|Eurostat]] Eurobarometer Poll of 2005, 67% of the population of Croatia responded that "they believe there is a God". [[CITE|240|https://scribd.com/doc/15826619/John-Wilkes-The-Illyrians]] In a 2009 Gallup poll, 70% answered yes to the question "Is religion an important part of your daily life?". [[CITE|240|https://scribd.com/doc/15826619/John-Wilkes-The-Illyrians]] However, only 24% of the population attends religious services regularly. [[CITE|326|http://assets.pewresearch.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/11/2017/05/09154356/Central-and-Eastern-Europe-Topline_FINAL-FOR-PUBLICATION.pdf]]
Languages
Croatian is the official language of Croatia, and became the 24th official language of the European Union upon its accession in 2013.

[[CITE|3|http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2010_07_85_2422.html]] [[CITE|28|http://vecernji.hr/vijesti/hrvatski-postaje-24-sluzbeni-jezik-europske-unije-clanak-211879]] Minority languages are in official use in local government units where more than a third of population consists of national minorities or where local legislation defines so. Those languages are [[LINK|lang_en|Czech_language|Czech]], [[LINK|lang_en|Hungarian_language|Hungarian]], [[LINK|lang_en|Italian_language_in_Croatia|Italian]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ruthenian_language|Ruthenian]], [[LINK|lang_en|Serbian_language_in_Croatia|Serbian]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Slovakian_language|Slovakian]]. [[CITE|280|https://books.google.com/books?id=bdKLyie1M50C]]

According to the 2011 Census, 95.6% of citizens of Croatia declared Croatian as their native language, 1.2% declared Serbian as their native language, while no other language is represented in Croatia by more than 0.5% of native speakers among population of Croatia.

[[CITE|80|http://dzs.hr/Eng/censuses/census2011/results/htm/e01_01_08/e01_01_08_RH.html]] Croatian is one of the five spoken languages of the [[LINK|lang_en|South_Slavic_languages|Western South Slavic group]] and one of the eighteen spoken [[LINK|lang_en|Slavic_languages|Slavic languages]]. Croatian is written using the Latin alphabet. It has three major [[LINK|lang_en|Dialect|dialects]] represented, with standard Croatian based on the [[LINK|lang_en|Shtokavian_dialect|Shtokavian dialect]]. The [[LINK|lang_en|Chakavian_dialect|Chakavian]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Kajkavian_dialect|Kajkavian]] dialects are distinguished by their [[LINK|lang_en|Lexicon|lexicon]], [[LINK|lang_en|Phonology|phonology]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Syntax|syntax]]. [[CITE|133|http://ihjj.hr/oHrJeziku-povijest-1.html]]

From 1961 to 1991, the official language was [[LINK|lang_en|Serbo-Croatian|Serbo-Croatian]]. Even during [[LINK|lang_en|Socialism|socialist rule]], Croats always referred to their language as Croatian, instead of Serbo-Croatian. [[CITE|280|https://books.google.com/books?id=bdKLyie1M50C]] Croatian and Serbian variants of the language were not officially recognised as different at the time, but referred to as the west and east version, and had different alphabets: the [[LINK|lang_en|Latin_alphabet|Latin alphabet]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Serbian_Cyrillic_alphabet|Serbian Cyrillic]]. [[CITE|133|http://ihjj.hr/oHrJeziku-povijest-1.html]] Croatians are protective of their Croatian language from foreign influences, as the language was under constant change and threats imposed by previous rulers (i.e. Austrian German, Hungarian, Italian and Turkish words were changed and altered to Slavic looking or sounding ones). Efforts made to impose policies to alter Croatian into "Serbo-Croatian" or "South Slavic" language, met resistance from Croats in form of [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_linguistic_purism|Croatian linguistic purism]]. Croatian replaced [[LINK|lang_en|Latin_language|Latin]] as the official language of the Croatian government in the 19th century. [[CITE|300|http://worldcat.org/issn/1845-6839]]
A 2011 survey revealed that 78% of Croatians claim knowledge of at least one foreign language.

[[CITE|329|http://index.hr/vijesti/clanak/istrazivanje-tri-posto-visokoobrazovanih-ne-zna-niti-jedan-strani-jezik-hrvati-uglavnom-znaju-engleski/545687.aspx]] According to a survey ordered by the [[LINK|lang_en|European_Commission|European Commission]] in 2005, 49% of Croatians speak English as the second language, 34% speak German, and 14% speak Italian. French and Russian are spoken by 4% each, and 2% of Croatians speak Spanish. However, there are large municipalities [[LINK|lang_en|Minority_languages_of_Croatia|that have minority languages]] that include substantial populations that speak these languages. An odd-majority of Slovenes (59%) have a certain level of knowledge of Croatian. [[CITE|355|http://ec.europa.eu/public_opinion/archives/ebs/ebs_243_en.pdf]] The country is a part of various language-based international associations most notably, the [[LINK|lang_en|Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie|Organisation internationale de la Francophonie]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Languages_of_the_European_Union|European Union Language Association.]]
Education
Literacy in Croatia stands at 99.2 per cent.

[[CITE|280|https://books.google.com/books?id=bdKLyie1M50C]] A worldwide study about the quality of living in different countries published by *[[LINK|lang_en|Newsweek|Newsweek]] * in August 2010 ranked the Croatian education system at 22nd, to share the position with Austria. [[CITE|46|https://webcitation.org/5sQWPP1Ay?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.newsweek.com%2F2010%2F08%2F15%2Finteractive-infographic-of-the-worlds-best-countries.html]] Primary education in Croatia starts at the age of six or seven and consists of eight grades. In 2007 a law was passed to increase free, noncompulsory education until 18 years of age. Compulsory education consists of eight grades of elementary school. Secondary education is provided by [[LINK|lang_en|Gymnasium_(school)|gymnasiums]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Vocational_school|vocational schools]]. As of 2014, there are 2,055 elementary schools and 707 schools providing various forms of secondary education. [[CITE|79|http://dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2016/sljh2016.pdf]] Primary and secondary education are also available in languages of recognized minorities in Croatia, where classes are held in Czech, Hungarian, Italian, Serbian and German languages.

There are 132 elementary and secondary level [[LINK|lang_en|Music_school|music]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Art_schools|art schools]], as well as 120 schools for disabled children and youth and 74 schools for adults. [[CITE|79|http://dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2016/sljh2016.pdf]] Nationwide [[LINK|lang_en|Matura|leaving exams]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_language|Croatian]]: *državna matura*) were introduced for secondary education students in the school year 2009–2010. It comprises three compulsory subjects (Croatian language, mathematics, and a foreign language) and optional subjects and is a prerequisite for university education. [[CITE|177|http://public.mzos.hr/Default.aspx?sec=2246]]

Croatia has 8 public universities, the [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_Dubrovnik|University of Dubrovnik]], [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_Osijek|University of Osijek]], [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_Pula|University of Pula]], [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_Rijeka|University of Rijeka]], [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_Split|University of Split]], [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_Zadar|University of Zadar]] and [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_Zagreb|University of Zagreb]], and 2 private universities, [[LINK|lang_en|Catholic_University_of_Croatia|Catholic University of Croatia]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Dubrovnik_International_University|Dubrovnik International University]]. [[CITE|231|http://iro.hr/hr/informiranje-i-savjetovanje-o-visokom-obrazovanju/studiranje-u-hrvatskoj/pregled-institucija]] The University of Zadar, the first university in Croatia, was founded in 1396 and remained active until 1807, when other institutions of higher education took over until the foundation of the renewed University of Zadar in 2002. [[CITE|293|http://unizd.hr/Onama/tabid/55/Default.aspx]] The University of Zagreb, founded in 1669, is the oldest continuously operating university in Southeast Europe. [[CITE|322|http://unizg.hr/homepage/about-university/history]] There are also 15 [[LINK|lang_en|Institute_of_technology|polytechnics]], of which 2 are private, and 30 higher education institutions, of which 27 are private. [[CITE|231|http://iro.hr/hr/informiranje-i-savjetovanje-o-visokom-obrazovanju/studiranje-u-hrvatskoj/pregled-institucija]] In total, there are 55 institutions of higher education in Croatia, attended by more than 157 thousand students. [[CITE|79|http://dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2016/sljh2016.pdf]]
There are 205 companies, government or education system institutions and non-profit organisations in Croatia pursuing scientific research and development of technology.
Combined, they spent more than 3 billion kuna (€400 million) and employed 10,191 full-time research staff in 2008.

[[CITE|84|http://dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2010/SLJH2010.pdf]] Among the scientific institutes operating in Croatia, the largest is the [[LINK|lang_en|Ruđer_Bošković_Institute|Ruđer Bošković Institute]] in Zagreb. [[CITE|350|http://jutarnji.hr/ciklotron--spojevi-i-novi-katalizatori---to-je-institut-ruder-boskovic-dao-svijetu-/823851]] The [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts|Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts]] in Zagreb is a [[LINK|lang_en|Learned_society|learned society]] promoting language, culture, arts and science from its inception in 1866. [[CITE|22|http://info.hazu.hr/foundation_of_academy]] Croatia has also [[LINK|lang_en|Category:Croatian_inventors|produced inventors]] and [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_country#Croatia|two Croatians]] received the Nobel Prize.

caption.text: Croatia became a member of the [[LINK|lang_en|European_Union|European Union]] on 1 July 2013

items.text: Health

Croatia has a [[LINK|lang_en|Universal_health_care|universal health care]] system, whose roots can be traced back to the Hungarian-Croatian Parliament Act of 1891, providing a form of mandatory insurance of all factory workers and craftsmen. [[CITE|85|http://worldcat.org/issn/1330-2965]] The population is covered by a basic health insurance plan provided by statute and optional insurance. In 2012, annual healthcare related expenditures reached 21.0 billion kuna (€2.8 billion). Healthcare expenditures comprise only 0.6% of private health insurance and public spending. [[CITE|137|http://vjesnik.hr/Article.aspx?ID=B02A10F4-BFE5-4EC0-B0E5-BFCAFE8F2062]] In 2010, Croatia spent 6.9% of its GDP on healthcare. [[CITE|166|http://go.worldbank.org/R62VSWTTU0]] Croatia ranked around the 40th in the world in life expectancy with 74 years for men and 81 years for women, and it had a low [[LINK|lang_en|Infant_mortality_rate|infant mortality rate]] of 5 per 1,000 [[LINK|lang_en|Live_birth_(human)|live births]]. [[CITE|369|http://gamapserver.who.int/gho/interactive_charts/mbd/life_expectancy/atlas.html]] [[CITE|203|http://who.int/countries/hrv/en]]
There are hundreds of healthcare institutions in Croatia, including 79 hospitals and clinics with 23,967 beds.

The hospitals and clinics care for more than 700 thousand patients per year and employ 5,205 [[LINK|lang_en|Doctor_of_Medicine|medical doctors]], including 3,929 specialists. There are 6,379 private practice offices, and a total of 41,271 health workers in the country. There are 63 emergency medical service units, responding to more than a million calls. The principal cause of death in 2008 was [[LINK|lang_en|Cardiovascular_disease|cardiovascular disease]] at 43.5% for men and 57.2% for women, followed by tumours, at 29.4% for men and 21.4% for women. In 2009 only 13 Croatians had been infected with HIV/AIDS and 6 had died from the disease. [[CITE|84|http://dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2010/SLJH2010.pdf]] In 2008 it was estimated by the WHO that 27.4% of Croatians over age of 15 are smokers. [[CITE|249|http://poslovni.hr/vijesti/u-hrvatskoj-se-pusi-manje-nego-u-eu-66591.aspx]] According to 2003 WHO data, 22% of the Croatian adult population is obese. [[CITE|279|http://apps.who.int/whosis/database/core/core_select_process.cfm]]

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Air_Force|Croatian Air Force]] and [[LINK|lang_en|US_Navy|US Navy]] aircraft participate in multinational training, 2002

items.text: Culture
Because of its geographic position, Croatia represents a blend of four different cultural spheres.

It has been a crossroad of influences of the western culture and the east—ever since division of the [[LINK|lang_en|Western_Roman_Empire|Western Roman Empire]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Byzantine_Empire|Byzantine Empire]] —as well as of the [[LINK|lang_en|Mitteleuropa|Mitteleuropa]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Mediterranean_culture|Mediterranean culture]]. [[CITE|320|http://croatia.hr/en-GB/Discover-Croatia/Culture-and-History]] The Illyrian movement was the most significant period of national cultural history, as the 19th-century period proved crucial in emancipation of the Croatian language and saw unprecedented developments in all fields of art and culture, giving rise to a number of [[LINK|lang_en|Culture_of_Croatia#People|historical figures]]. [[CITE|346|http://worldcat.org/issn/1332-2567]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|Ministry_of_Culture_(Croatia)|Ministry of Culture]] of the Republic of Croatia is tasked with preserving the nation's [[LINK|lang_en|Natural_and_Cultural_Heritage_of_Croatia|cultural and natural heritage]] and overseeing its development. Further activities supporting development of culture are undertaken at local government level. [[CITE|347|http://min-kulture.hr/default.aspx?id=348]] The [[LINK|lang_en|UNESCO|UNESCO]]'s [[LINK|lang_en|Table_of_World_Heritage_Sites_by_country|World Heritage List]] includes seven sites in Croatia. [[CITE|31|http://worldheritagesite.org/countries/croatia.html]] The country is also rich with [[LINK|lang_en|Intangible_culture|Intangible culture]] and holds ten of [[LINK|lang_en|Representative_List_of_the_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_of_Humanity|UNESCO's World's intangible culture masterpieces]], surpassing all countries in Europe except Spain which possesses an equal number of the listed items. [[CITE|55|http://unesco.org/culture/ich/index.php?display1=countryIDs&lg=en&multinational=3&pg=00011#tabs]] A global cultural contribution from Croatia is the necktie, derived from the [[LINK|lang_en|Cravat|cravat]] originally worn by the 17th-century Croatian mercenaries in France. [[CITE|83|https://nytimes.com/1995/07/30/magazine/style-dressed-to-kill.html]] [[CITE|120|http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=43829&show=clanak]]
As of 2012, Croatia has 60 professional theatres, 17 professional children's theatres and 60 amateur theatres visited by more than 1.8 million viewers per year.
The professional theatres employ 1,121 artists.
There are 23 professional orchestras, ensembles and choirs in the country, attracting an annual attendance of 294 thousand.
There are 162 cinemas with attendance exceeding 4 million.
Croatia has 175 museums, visited by nearly 2.2 million people in 2009.
Furthermore, there are 1,731 libraries in the country, containing 24.5 million volumes, and 18 archives.
In 2009, more than 7,200 books and brochures were published, along with 2,678 magazines and 314 newspapers.
There are also 146 radio stations and 21 TV stations operating in the country.
In past five years, film production in Croatia produced up to five feature films and 10 to 51 short films, with an additional 76 to 112 TV films.
As of 2009, there are 784 amateur cultural and artistic associations and more than 10 thousand cultural, educational and artistic events held annually.

[[CITE|84|http://dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2010/SLJH2010.pdf]] The book publishing market is dominated by several major publishers and the industry's centrepiece event— [[LINK|lang_en|Interliber|Interliber]] exhibition held annually at [[LINK|lang_en|Zagreb_Fair|Zagreb Fair]]. [[CITE|207|http://jutarnji.hr/interliber--nobelovci-za-20--bestseleri-za-50--remek-djela-za-100-kuna/902783]]

Croatia is categorised as having established a very high level of human development in the [[LINK|lang_en|Human_Development_Index|Human Development Index]], with a high degree of equality in HDI achievements between women and men. [[CITE|218|http://hdr.undp.org/sites/default/files/2016_human_development_report.pdf]] It promotes [[LINK|lang_en|Disability_rights_movement|disability rights]]. [[CITE|270|http://www.delhrv.ec.europa.eu/?content=1869&lang=en]] [[LINK|lang_en|Recognition_of_same-sex_unions_in_Croatia|Recognition of same-sex unions in Croatia]] has gradually improved over the past decade, culminating in registered [[LINK|lang_en|Civil_unions|civil unions]] in July 2014, granting same-sex couples equal inheritance rights, tax deductions and limited adoption rights. [[CITE|291|http://pinknews.co.uk/2014/07/15/croatia-passes-civil-partnerships-law]] However, in December 2013 Croatians voted in favour of a [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_constitutional_referendum,_2013|constitutional referendum]], backed by conservative groups, defining marriage as a "life union of woman and man". [[CITE|321|http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/12/01/uk-croatia-referendum-idUKBRE9B005V20131201]]

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|M-95_Degman|M-95 Degman]], a prototype Croatian main battle tank

items.text: Arts and literature
Architecture in Croatia reflects influences of bordering nations.
Austrian and Hungarian influence is visible in public spaces and buildings in the north and in the central regions, architecture found along coasts of Dalmatia and Istria exhibits Venetian influence.

[[CITE|345|https://books.google.com/books?id=_G43AAAAIAAJ]] Large squares named after culture heroes, well-groomed parks, and pedestrian-only zones, are features of these orderly towns and cities, especially where large scale [[LINK|lang_en|Baroque_architecture|Baroque]] urban planning took place, for instance in Osijek ([[LINK|lang_en|Tvrđa|Tvrđa]]), Varaždin and Karlovac. [[CITE|372|http://telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/europe/croatia/10124483/Varazdin-Croatias-little-Vienna.html]] [[CITE|26|http://jutarnji.hr/najljepsi-gradovi-sjeverne-hrvatske---karlovac--ozalj--ogulin/877654]] Subsequent influence of the [[LINK|lang_en|Art_Nouveau|Art Nouveau]] was reflected in contemporary architecture. [[CITE|88|http://hart.hr/uploads/documents/354.pdf]] Along the coast, the architecture is Mediterranean with a strong Venetian and Renaissance influence in major urban areas exemplified in works of [[LINK|lang_en|Giorgio_da_Sebenico|Giorgio da Sebenico]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Niccolò_Fiorentino|Niccolò Fiorentino]] such as the [[LINK|lang_en|Šibenik_Cathedral|Cathedral of St. James]] in Šibenik. The oldest preserved examples of Croatian architecture are the 9th-century churches, with the largest and the most representative among them being [[LINK|lang_en|Church_of_St._Donatus|Church of St. Donatus]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Zadar|Zadar]]. [[CITE|130|http://mfa.hr/MVP.asp?pcpid=1467]] [[CITE|232|http://tzzadar.hr/en/city-guide/historical-monuments/23-05-2007/church-of-saint-donat]]
Besides the architecture encompassing the oldest artworks in Croatia, there is a long history of artists in Croatia reaching to the Middle Ages.

In that period the stone portal of the [[LINK|lang_en|Trogir_Cathedral|Trogir Cathedral]] was made by [[LINK|lang_en|Radovan_(master)|Radovan]], representing the most important monument of [[LINK|lang_en|Romanesque_art|Romanesque]] sculpture from [[LINK|lang_en|Croatia_in_the_union_with_Hungary|Medieval Croatia]]. The [[LINK|lang_en|Renaissance_in_Croatia|Renaissance]] had the greatest impact on the Adriatic Sea coast since the remainder of Croatia was embroiled in the Hundred Years' Croatian–Ottoman War. With the waning of the Ottoman Empire, art flourished during the [[LINK|lang_en|Baroque|Baroque]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Rococo|Rococo]]. The 19th and the 20th centuries brought about affirmation of numerous Croatian artisans, helped by several patrons of the arts such as bishop [[LINK|lang_en|Josip_Juraj_Strossmayer|Josip Juraj Strossmayer]]. [[CITE|292|http://worldcat.org/issn/1847-6236]] Croatian artists of the period achieving worldwide renown were [[LINK|lang_en|Vlaho_Bukovac|Vlaho Bukovac]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Ivan_Meštrović|Ivan Meštrović]]. [[CITE|130|http://mfa.hr/MVP.asp?pcpid=1467]]

The Baška tablet, a stone inscribed with the [[LINK|lang_en|Glagolitic_alphabet|glagolitic alphabet]] found on the Krk island and dated to 1100, is considered to be the oldest surviving prose in Croatian. [[CITE|314|http://krk.hr/en/offer/attractions/the_baska_tablet]] The beginning of more vigorous development of Croatian literature is marked by the Renaissance and [[LINK|lang_en|Marko_Marulić|Marko Marulić]]. Besides Marulić, Renaissance playwright [[LINK|lang_en|Marin_Držić|Marin Držić]], Baroque poet [[LINK|lang_en|Ivan_Gundulić|Ivan Gundulić]], [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_national_revival|Croatian national revival]] poet [[LINK|lang_en|Ivan_Mažuranić|Ivan Mažuranić]], novelist, playwright and poet [[LINK|lang_en|August_Šenoa|August Šenoa]], children's writer [[LINK|lang_en|Ivana_Brlić-Mažuranić|Ivana Brlić-Mažuranić]], writer and journalist [[LINK|lang_en|Marija_Jurić_Zagorka|Marija Jurić Zagorka]], poet and writer [[LINK|lang_en|Antun_Gustav_Matoš|Antun Gustav Matoš]], poet [[LINK|lang_en|Antun_Branko_Šimić|Antun Branko Šimić]], [[LINK|lang_en|Expressionism|expressionist]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Realism_(arts)|realist]] writer [[LINK|lang_en|Miroslav_Krleža|Miroslav Krleža]], poet [[LINK|lang_en|Tin_Ujević|Tin Ujević]] and novelist and short story writer [[LINK|lang_en|Ivo_Andrić|Ivo Andrić]] are often cited as the greatest figures in Croatian literature. [[CITE|360|http://lzmk.hr/hr/vijesti-zavoda/iz-medija/524-hrvatska-knjizevnost-u-270000-redaka-vjesnik]] [[CITE|12|https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?pagewanted=all&res=9F0CE7D91531F93BA25757C0A965958260&sec=&spon=]]

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Istria|Istrian]] vineyards; [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_wine|Wine]] is produced in nearly all regions of Croatia

items.text: Media
The freedom of the press and the freedom of speech are guaranteed by the constitution of Croatia.

[[CITE|30|http://pressreference.com/Co-Fa/Croatia.html]] Croatia ranked 62nd in the 2010 [[LINK|lang_en|Press_Freedom_Index|Press Freedom Index]] report compiled by [[LINK|lang_en|Reporters_Without_Borders|Reporters Without Borders]]. [[CITE|74|http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html]] The state-owned news agency [[LINK|lang_en|HINA|HINA]] runs a [[LINK|lang_en|Wire_service|wire service]] in Croatian and English on politics, economics, society and culture. [[CITE|126|http://websrv2.hina.hr/hina/web/view.action?view=hina]]

Despite the provisions fixed in the constitution, freedoms of press and speech in Croatia have been classified as partly free since 2000 by [[LINK|lang_en|Freedom_House|Freedom House]], the independent nongovernmental organisation that monitors press freedom worldwide. Namely the country has been ranked 85th (of 196 countries), [[CITE|-1|http://freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/FOTP2011%20Tables%20and%20Graphs_0.pdf]] and the 2011 Freedom House report noted improvement of applicable legislation reflecting Croatia's accession to the EU, yet pointed out instances of politicians' attempts to hinder [[LINK|lang_en|Investigative_journalism|investigative journalism]] and influence news reports contents, difficulties regarding [[LINK|lang_en|Freedom_of_information|public access to information]], and that most of print media market is controlled by German-owned [[LINK|lang_en|Hanza_Media|Hanza Media]] and Austrian-owned [[LINK|lang_en|Styria_Media_Group|Styria Media Group]]. [[CITE|233|http://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2011/croatia]] [[LINK|lang_en|Amnesty_International|Amnesty International]] reports that in 2009 in Croatia there was an increase in the number of physical attacks and murders of journalists. The incidents were mainly perpetrated against journalists investigating war crimes and organised crime. [[CITE|295|http://report2009.amnesty.org/en/regions/europe-central-asia/croatia]]

As of October 2011, there are nine nationwide free-to-air DVB-T television channels, with [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Radiotelevision|Croatian Radiotelevision]] (HRT), [[LINK|lang_en|Nova_TV_(Croatia)|Nova TV]] and [[LINK|lang_en|RTL_Televizija|RTL Televizija]] operating two of the channels each, and the remaining three operated by the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Olympic_Committee|Croatian Olympic Committee]], Kapital Net d.o.o. and Author d.o.o. companies. In addition there are 21 regional or local DVB-T television channels. [[CITE|318|http://oiv.hr/broadcasting/tables/dtv_channel_hr.aspx]] The HRT is also broadcasting a satellite TV channel. [[CITE|341|http://hrt.hr/index.php?cHash=ac69c865cd&id=186&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=185&tx_ttnews%5Bcat%5D=126&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=1787]] In 2016, there were 135 radio stations and 25 TV stations in Croatia. Cable television and [[LINK|lang_en|IPTV|IPTV]] networks are gaining ground in the country, as the cable TV networks already serve 450 thousand people, 10% of the total population of the country. [[CITE|17|http://liderpress.hr/Default.aspx?sid=11836]] [[CITE|39|http://jutarnji.hr/kabelska-televizija--vec-je-450--tisuca-hrvata-preslo-na-kabelsku-i-gleda-200-tv-programa/901119]]
There are 314 newspapers and 2,678 magazines published in Croatia.

[[CITE|84|http://dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2010/SLJH2010.pdf]] The print media market is dominated by [[LINK|lang_en|Europapress_Holding|Europapress Holding]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Styria_Media_Group|Styria Media Group]] who publish their flagship dailies *[[LINK|lang_en|Jutarnji_list|Jutarnji list]] *, *[[LINK|lang_en|Večernji_list|Večernji list]] * and *[[LINK|lang_en|24sata_(Croatia)|24sata]] *. Other influential newspapers are *[[LINK|lang_en|Novi_list|Novi list]] * and *[[LINK|lang_en|Slobodna_Dalmacija|Slobodna Dalmacija]] *. [[CITE|86|http://eph.hr/eng/products_and_services/index.html]] [[CITE|135|http://styria.com/en/konzernunternehmen/kategorie.php?cat=1]] In 2013, *24sata* was the most widely circulated daily newspaper, followed by *Večernji list* and *Jutarnji list*. [[CITE|183|http://hrcak.srce.hr/135683]]

[[LINK|lang_en|Cinema_of_Croatia|Croatia's film industry]] is small and heavily subsidised by the government, mainly through grants approved by the Ministry of Culture with films often being co-produced by HRT. [[CITE|254|http://jutarnji.hr/ministarstvo-financira-rekordan-broj-filmova/154303]] [[CITE|290|http://hrt.hr/index.php?cHash=348879aae9&id=94&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=23&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=108897]] [[LINK|lang_en|Pula_Film_Festival|Pula Film Festival]], the national film awards event held annually in [[LINK|lang_en|Pula|Pula]], is the most prestigious film event featuring national and international productions. [[CITE|333|http://vjesnik.hr/Article.aspx?ID=4D920144-9B74-462C-82CF-ED90611927CA]] The greatest accomplishment by Croatian filmmakers was achieved by [[LINK|lang_en|Dušan_Vukotić|Dušan Vukotić]] when he won the 1961 [[LINK|lang_en|Academy_Award_for_Best_Animated_Short_Film|Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film]] for *[[LINK|lang_en|Surogat|Ersatz]] * ([[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_language|Croatian]]: *Surogat*). [[CITE|2|http://vjesnik.hr/Article.aspx?ID=7C537DEE-B4AE-4879-9F79-7C68D6294510]]
Cuisine
Croatian traditional cuisine varies from one region to another.

Dalmatia and Istria draw upon culinary influences of [[LINK|lang_en|Italian_cuisine|Italian]] and other [[LINK|lang_en|Mediterranean_cuisine|Mediterranean cuisines]] which prominently feature various seafood, cooked vegetables and pasta, as well as condiments such as olive oil and garlic. The continental cuisine is heavily influenced by [[LINK|lang_en|Hungarian_cuisine|Hungarian]], [[LINK|lang_en|Austrian_cuisine|Austrian]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Turkish_cuisine|Turkish]] culinary styles. In that area, meats, freshwater fish and vegetable dishes are predominant. [[CITE|21|http://croatia.hr/en-GB/Discover-Croatia/Gastronomy-and-enology]]
There are two distinct wine-producing regions in Croatia.
The continental region in the northeast of the country, especially Slavonia, is capable of producing premium wines, particularly whites.
Along the north coast, Istrian and Krk wines are similar to those produced in neighbouring Italy, while further south in Dalmatia, Mediterranean-style red wines are the norm.
[[CITE|21|http://croatia.hr/en-GB/Discover-Croatia/Gastronomy-and-enology]] Annual production of wine exceeds 140 million litres.

[[CITE|84|http://dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2010/SLJH2010.pdf]] Croatia was almost exclusively a wine-consuming country up until the late 18th century when a more massive production and consumption of beer started; [[CITE|52|http://matica.hr/HRRevija/revija032.nsf/AllWebDocs/skenderovic]] the annual consumption of beer in 2008 was 83.3 litres per capita which placed Croatia in 15th place among the world's countries. [[CITE|69|http://kirinholdings.co.jp/english/news/2009/1221_01.html]]
Sports
There are more than 400,000 active sportspeople in Croatia.

[[CITE|102|http://worldcat.org/issn/1847-6376]] Out of that number, 277,000 are members of sports associations and nearly 4,000 are members of chess and [[LINK|lang_en|Contract_bridge|contract bridge]] associations. [[CITE|84|http://dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2010/SLJH2010.pdf]] Association football is the most popular sport. The [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Football_Federation|Croatian Football Federation]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_language|Croatian]]: *Hrvatski nogometni savez*), with more than 118,000 registered players, is the largest sporting association in the country. [[CITE|127|http://hns-cff.hr/?ln=en&w=o_hns]] The [[LINK|lang_en|Prva_HNL|Prva HNL]] football league attracts the highest [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_attendance_figures_at_domestic_professional_sports_leagues|average attendance]] of any professional sports league in the country. In season 2010–11, it attracted 458,746 spectators. [[CITE|156|http://index.hr/sport/clanak/evo-vam-lige-16-na-utakmicama-hnla-prosjecno-1911-ljudi/553229.aspx]]

Croatian athletes competing at international events since Croatian independence in 1991 won 44 [[LINK|lang_en|Croatia_at_the_Olympics|Olympic medals]], including fifteen gold medals—at the [[LINK|lang_en|1996_Summer_Olympics|1996]] and [[LINK|lang_en|2004_Summer_Olympics|2004 Summer Olympics]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Handball|handball]], [[LINK|lang_en|2000_Summer_Olympics|2000 Summer Olympics]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Olympic_weightlifting|weightlifting]], [[LINK|lang_en|2002_Winter_Olympics|2002]] and [[LINK|lang_en|2006_Winter_Olympics|2006 Winter Olympics]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Alpine_skiing|alpine skiing]], [[LINK|lang_en|2012_Summer_Olympics|2012 Summer Olympics]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Discus_throw|discus throw]], [[LINK|lang_en|Trap_shooting|trap shooting]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Water_polo|water polo]], and in [[LINK|lang_en|2016_Summer_Olympics|2016 Summer Olympics]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Shooting_sport|shooting]], [[LINK|lang_en|Rowing_(sport)|rowing]], [[LINK|lang_en|Discus_throw_at_the_Olympics|discus throw]], [[LINK|lang_en|Sailing_(sport)|sailing]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Javelin_throw_at_the_Olympics|javelin throw]]. [[CITE|216|http://hoo.hr/en/olimpijske_popis.aspx]] In addition, Croatian athletes won 16 gold medals at world championships, including four in athletics at the World Championships in Athletics held in [[LINK|lang_en|2007_World_Championships_in_Athletics|2007]], [[LINK|lang_en|2009_World_Championships_in_Athletics|2009]], [[LINK|lang_en|2013_World_Championships_in_Athletics|2013]] and [[LINK|lang_en|2017_World_Championships_in_Athletics|2017]], one in handball at the [[LINK|lang_en|2003_World_Men's_Handball_Championship|2003 World Men's Handball Championship]], two in water polo at the [[LINK|lang_en|2007_World_Aquatics_Championships|2007 World Aquatics Championships]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Water_polo_at_the_2017_World_Aquatics_Championships|2017 World Aquatics Championships]], one in rowing at the [[LINK|lang_en|2010_World_Rowing_Championships|2010 World Rowing Championships]], six in alpine skiing at the [[LINK|lang_en|FIS_Alpine_World_Ski_Championships_2003|FIS Alpine World Ski Championships held in 2003]] and [[LINK|lang_en|FIS_Alpine_World_Ski_Championships_2005|2005]] and two at the World Taekwondo Championships in [[LINK|lang_en|2011_World_Taekwondo_Championships|2011]] and [[LINK|lang_en|2007_World_Taekwondo_Championships|2007]]. Croatian athletes also won the [[LINK|lang_en|2005_Davis_Cup|2005 Davis Cup]].

Croatia hosted several major sport competitions, including the [[LINK|lang_en|2009_World_Men's_Handball_Championship|2009 World Men's Handball Championship]], the [[LINK|lang_en|2007_World_Table_Tennis_Championships|2007 World Table Tennis Championships]], the [[LINK|lang_en|2000_World_Rowing_Championships|2000 World Rowing Championships]], the [[LINK|lang_en|1987_Summer_Universiade|1987 Summer Universiade]], the [[LINK|lang_en|1979_Mediterranean_Games|1979 Mediterranean Games]] and several [[LINK|lang_en|European_Championship|European Championships]]. The governing sports authority in the country is the [[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_Olympic_Committee|Croatian Olympic Committee]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Croatian_language|Croatian]]: *Hrvatski olimpijski odbor*), founded on 10 September 1991 and recognised by the [[LINK|lang_en|International_Olympic_Committee|International Olympic Committee]] since 17 January 1992, in time to permit the Croatian athletes to appear at the [[LINK|lang_en|1992_Winter_Olympics|1992 Winter Olympics]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Albertville|Albertville]], France representing the newly independent nation for the first time at the [[LINK|lang_en|Olympic_Games|Olympic Games]]. [[CITE|278|http://hoo.hr/en/hoo.aspx]]
